publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: TIs true ſhe is a right good Princes, and a juſt one;
And Florence when ſhe ſets has loſt a Planet.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My Miſtris? I tell thee gentle Nephew,
There is not ſuch another friend to goodneſſe,
To down-right dealing, to faith and true heart
Within the Chriſtian confines: Before ſhe bleſt us,
Juſtice was a Cheeſe-monger; a meere Cheeſe-monger,
Weigh'd nothing to the World but mytes and maggots,
And a maine ſtinke: Law like a Horſe-courſer,
Her rules, and precepts hung with gawdes and ribbonds,
And pamper'd up to couſen him that bought her,
When ſhe her ſelfe was hackney lame and founder'd.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: But the ſweet Lady,
Belvidere the bright one—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I, there's a face indeed: O my deare Nephew;
Could a young fellow of thy fiery mettle
Freeze, and that Lady in his armes?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I think not.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou haſt a parlous judgement; but let that paſſe,
She is as truly vertuous, faire, and noble,
As her great Mother's good; and that's not ordinary.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: But why (ſo many Princes, and ſo great ones
Being Suitors) ſhould the Dutcheſſe deny to match her?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: She is a Jewell man, hangs in her boſome,
Her only Childe: with her eyes ſhe ſees all things,
Diſcourſes with her tongue, and pluck her from her
(So dotingly the old one loves her young one)
You pluck her heart out too: Beſides, of late daies,
The Duke of Millaine, who could never win her
By love, nor treaty, laid a cloſe traine for her
In her owne private walkes: ſome forty Horſe-men,
So to ſurprize her; which we found, and dealt with,
And ſent 'em running home to the Duke their Maſter,
Like Doggs with bottles at their tailes.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Since that, I heard Sir,
She has ſent her to your Cittadell to ſecure her,
My couſen Rodope, your wife attending her.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You heare a truth, and all convenient pleaſures
Are there proportion'd for her.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I would faine Sir,
Like one that owes a dutious ſervice to her
Sometimes, ſo pleaſe you—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Gentle Couſen pardon me,
I muſt not, nor you muſt not dare to offer,
The laſt Edict lyes on his life pu●ſues it;
Your friend Sir to command, abroad to love you,
To lend ye any thing I have, to wait upon ye,
But in the Cittadell where I ſtand charg'd,
Not a bit upon a march: no ſervice Sir,
No, good Sir by no meanes: I kiſſe your hands Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: To your keeping only? none elſe to look upon her?
None but Bartello worthy her attendance?
No faith but his to ſerve her? O Belvidere,
Thou Saint to whom my youth is ſacrific'd,
Thou point to which my life turnes, and my fortune,
Art thou lock'd from me now? from all my comforts,
Art thou ſnatch'd violently? thou hear'ſt me not,
Nor canſt thou ſee (faire ſoule) thy Servants mournings,
Yet let thy gentle heart feele what is abſence,
The great divorſe of minds ſo truly loving,
So long, and nurs'd in one affection
Even from our infant eyes, ſuck'd in and nouriſh'd:
O let it feele but that, and there ſtand conſtant
And I am bleſt. My deare Neece Rodope,
That is her Governeſſe, did love me dearely,
There's one hope yet to ſee her: when he is abſent
It may be ventur'd, and ſhe may work it cloſely:
I know the Ladies will goes equall with me,
And ſo the danger of the Edict avoyded;
Let me think more, for I muſt try all hazards.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Will ye go yonder Sir?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yes marry will I Sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: And by this Ladder?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: By that Ladder, coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Have ye any more necks at home when this is broken,
For this will crack with the beſt friend he has Sir?
Or can you pitch of all foure, like an Ape now?
Let me ſee you tumble.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You are very pleaſant Sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: No truly Sir, I ſhould be loath to ſee ye
Come fluttering down like a yong Rooke, cry ſquab,
And take ye up with your brains beaten into your buttocks

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Hold your peace Aſſe: who's this ſtands muſing here?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Who calls me?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: One moſt glad to ſee you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: My deareſt Claudio? what make you thus private,
And with a preparation of this nature?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.p: We have leave to play, and are going to climbe Birds neſts.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Prethee what is it friend? why ſtart ye from me?
Is your old Miſtris growne ſo coy and cruell,
She muſt be ſcal'd? it ſeemes you are loath to tell me,
Since twenty yeares continuance of our friendſhip
May not be worth the weight of ſuch a ſecret,
'Twill be but rude to aske againe: 'ſave ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay ſtay, deare Silvio, if you love me take it:
For till you know it, never woman labour'd
As I do now.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ile do my beſt to eaſe it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You have heard the Lady Belvidere—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What heard Sir?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Heard to the Cittadell, upon ſome feares
She is confin'd.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Why dreames he on this beauty?
'Tis true, I have heard it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And that no acceſſe,
No bleſſing from thoſe eyes but with much hazard,
Even hazard of a life.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: He dares not love her;
I have heard that too: but whither points your purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O Silvio, let me ſpeake that none may heare me,
None but thy truth: I have lov'd this Lady long,
Long given away my life to her devotion,
Long dwelt upon that beauty to my ruine.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Do's ſhe know this?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: No, there begins my miſery,
Ixion-like, I have onely yet claſp'd Clouds,
And fed upon poore empty dreames that ſtarve me.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And what do you meane to do now?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Though I dye for't,
Though all the tortures in the world hung on me,
Arm'd with imperious Love, I ſtand prepar'd now,
With this to reach her Chamber: there to ſee her,
And tell her boldly with what truth I love her.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Twill not be eaſily done Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O my Silvio,
The hardeſt things are ſweeteſt in poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Nor will ſhew much diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Love is blinde man,
And he that lookes for reaſon there far blinder.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Have ye conſider'd ripely?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: All that may fall,
And arm'd againſt that all.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Her honour too?
What ſhe may ſuffer in this raſh adventure?
The beauty of her name?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ile do it cloſely,
And only at her window, with that caution—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Are there no Guards?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Corruption chokes their ſervice.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Or do you hold her bred ſo light a woman
To hold commerce with ſtrange tongues?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why this ſervice,
This only hazard of my life muſt tell her,
Though ſhe were Veſtas ſelfe, I muſt deſerve her.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I would not have ye go: pray let it ſinke here,
And think a nobler way to raiſe your ſervice,
A ſafer, and a wiſer.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis too late Sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Then I muſt ſay, You ſhall not go.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I ſhall not?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You ſhall not go: that part bred with ye, friendſhip
Bids me ſay boldly ſo, and you obſerve me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You ſtretch that tye too far.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ile ſtretch it farther:
The honour that I beare that ſpotleſſe vertue
You fouly ſeeke to taint, unnobly covet,
Bids me command ye ſtay: if not, thus force ye.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: This will be worſe then climbing.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why do ye draw Sir?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: To kill thee, if thy baſe will be thy Maſter.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I ever was your friend.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Whilſt thou wert honeſt,
And not a Night-theife of anothers honour;
I never call'd a Foole my friend, a mad-man,
That durſt expoſe his fame to all opinions,
His life to unhoneſt dangers: I never lov'd him,
Durſt know his name, that ſought a Virgins ruine,
Nor ever tooke I pleaſure in acquaintance
With men, that give as looſe raynes to their fancies
As the wilde Ocean to his raging fluxes:
A noble ſoule I twin with, and my love
Followes, his life dares maſter his affections.
Will ye give off, or fight?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I will not fight with ye:
The ſacred name of friend tyes up that anger,
Rather ile ſtudy.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Do, to be a friend ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If this way, I ſhall never hold.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ile watch ye:
And if I catch ye falſe: by Heaven ye dye for't,
All love forgot.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: When I feare that I am fit for't. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Lopez at a Table with jewels and money upon it, an Egge roſting by a Candle.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Whilſt prodigall yong gaudy Fools are banqueting,
And launching out their ſtates to catch the giddy,
Thus do I ſtudy to preſerve my fortune,
And hatch with care at home the wealth that Saints me.
Here's Rubies of Bengala, rich, rich, glorious;
Theſe Diamonds of Ormus bought for little,
Here vented at the price of Princes Ranſomes;
How bright they ſhine like conſtellations,
The South ſeas treaſure here, Pearle, faire and orient
Able to equall Cleapatra's Banket,
Here chaines of leſſer ſtones for Ladies luſtres,
Ingotts of Gold, Rings, Brooches, barrs of Silver,
Theſe are my ſtudies to ſet off in ſale well,
And not in ſenſuall ſurfeits to conſume 'em;
How roſts mine egg? he heats apace, ile turne him:
Penurio, where you knave do you wait? Penurio,
You lazie knave.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Did you call Sir?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Where's your Miſtris?
What vanity holds her from her attendance?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The very ſight of this egge has made him cockiſh,
What would a dozen butter'd do? She is within Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Within Sir, at what thrift ye knave? what getting?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Getting a good ſtomack Sir, & ſhe knew where to get meat to it,
She is praying heartily upon her knees Sir,
That Heaven would ſend her a good bearing dinner.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Nothing but gluttony and ſurfeit thought on,
Health flung behinde: had ſhe not yeſternight firrah
Two Sprats to ſupper, and the oyle allowable?
Was ſhe not ſick with eating? Hadſt not thou,
(Thou moſt vngratefull knave, that nothing ſatisfies)
The water that I boyl'd my other egge in
To make thee hearty broth?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I had Sir;
But I might as ſoone make the Philoſophers Stone on't,
You gave it me in water, and but for manners ſake,
I could give it you againe in wind, it was ſo hearty
I ſhall turne piſſing Conduit ſhortly: my Miſtris comes Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Welcome my Dove.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Pray ye keep your welcome to ye,
Unleſſe it carries more then words to pleaſe me,
Is this the joy to be a Wife? to bring with me,
Beſides the nobleneſſe of blood I ſpring from,
A full and able portion to maintaine me?
Is this the happineſſe of youth and beauty,
The great content of being made a Miſtris,
To live a Slave ſubject to wants, and hungers,
To jealouſies for every eye that wanders?
Unmanly jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Good Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Too good for you: do you think to famiſh me,
Or keep me like an Almes-woman in ſuch rayment,
Such poore unhandſome weeds? am I old, or ugly?
I never was bred thus: and if your miſery
Will ſuffer wilfull blindneſſe to abuſe me,
My patience ſhall be no Bawd to mine owne ruine.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Tickle him Miſtris: to him.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Had ye love in ye,
Or any patt of man—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Follow that Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Or had humanity but ever knowne ye,
You would ſhame to uſe a woman of my way thus,
So poore, and baſely: you are ſtrangly jealous of me
If I ſhould give ye cauſe.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: How Iſabella?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: As do not venture this way to provoke me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Excellent well Miſtris,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: How's this Iſabella?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: 'Twill ſtir a Saint, and I am but a woman,
And by that tenure may.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: By no meanes Chicken,
You know I love ye: fie, take no example
By thoſe young gadding Dames: (you are noted vertuous)
That ſtick their Husbands wealth in trifles on 'em
And point 'em but the way to their owne miſeries:
I am not jealous, kiſſe me, — I am not:
And for your diet, 'tis to keep you healthfull,
Surfits deſtroy more then the ſword: that I am carefull
Your meat ſhould be both neat, and cleanly handled
See, Sweet, I am Cook my ſelfe, and mine owne Cater.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A — of that Cook cannot lick his fingers.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Ile adde another diſh: you ſhall have Milke to it,
'Tis nouriſhing and good.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: With Butter in't Sir?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This knave would breed a famine in a Kingdom:
And cloths that ſhall content ye: you muſt be wiſe then,
And live ſequeſtred to your ſelfe and me,
Not wandring after every toy comes croſſe ye,
Nor ſtrooke with every ſpleene: what's the knave doing? Penurio.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Hunting Sir, for a ſecond courſe of flyes here,
They are rare new Sallads.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: For certaine Iſabella
This ravening fellow has a Woolf in's belly:
Untemperate knave, will nothing quench thy appetite?
I ſaw him eat two Apples, which is monſtrous.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: If you had given me thoſe 'thad bin more monſtrōs.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: 'Tis a maine miracle to feed this villaine,
Come Iſabella, let us in to Supper,
And think the Romane dainties at our Table,
'Tis all but thought. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Would all my thoughts would do it:
The Devill ſhould think of purchaſing that Egge-ſhell,
To vittle out a Witch for the Burmoothes:
'Tis treaſon to any good ſtomack living now
To heare a tedious Grace ſaid, and no meat to 't,
I have a Radiſh yet, but that's but tranſitory. Exit.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Can any living man unleſſe a Raſcall
That neither knowes himſelfe, nor a faſhion'd Gentleman
Take me for a worſe man then my Maſter now?
I am naturally proud in theſe cloths: but if pride now
Should catch a fall in what I am attempting,
'Tis but a Proverb ſound, and a Neck broken,
That's the worſt can come on't: a Gentleman's gone then,
A Gentleman oth' firſt houſe, there's the end on't:
My Maſter lyes moſt pittifully complaining,
Wringing and kicking up toth' eares in love yonder,
And ſuch a lamentable noyſe he keepes, it kills me:
I have got his cloths, and if I can get to her
By hooke or crooke here, ſuch a ſong ile ſing her—
I think I ſhall be hang'd, but that's no matter,
What's a hanging among friends: I am valiant now as an Elephant;
What's a hanging among friends: I am valiant now as an
I have conſider'd what to ſay too: let me ſee now,
This is the place, 'tis plaguy high: ſtay at that lower window
Let me ayme finely now, like a good Gunner,
It may prove but a whipping.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I ſaw ſome-body
Paſſe by me now, and though it were dark, me thought yet
I knew the clothes: ha, let me not be cozen'd,
The Ladder too, ready to fling it? monſtrous,
'Tis he, 'tis Claudio: moſt voluptuous villaine,
Scandall to womans credit: Love, I forget thee.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: What will he do ith' name of heaven, what's that there?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And all the friendſhip that I bore thee, bury here.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: What has he in's hand? I hope but a Cudgell.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Thy fault's forgive O Heaven: farewell thou traitor.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I am ſlaine: I am ſlaine.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: He's downe, and dead: dead certaine,
'Twas too raſh, too full of ſpleene, ſtark dead:
This is no place now to repent in, onely
Would I had given this hand that ſhot the Piſtoll
I had miſſ'd thee, and thou wert once more Claudio. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why ſhould I love thus fooliſhly? thus deſperatly?
And give away my heart where no hope's left me?
Why ſhould not the true counſell of a friend reſtraine me?
The Devills mouth I run into affright me,
The honour of the Lady charme my wildneſſe;
I have no power, no being of my ſelfe,
No reaſon ſtrong enough now left within me
To binde my will: O Love, thou God, or Devill,
Or what thou art that playes the tyrant in me.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What's that cry?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: A Surgeon, a Surgeon,
Twenty good Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis not far from me,
Some Murther o' my life,

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Will you let me dye here?
No drink come, nor no Surgeon?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis my man ſure,
His voyce, and here he lyes: how is it with thee?

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.l: I am ſlaine, Sir, I am ſlaine.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Slaine? Who has ſlaine thee?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Kill'd, kill'd, out-right kill'd.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Where's thy hurt?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I know not,
But I am ſure I am kill'd.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Canſt thou ſit up,
That I may finde the hurt out?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I can ſit up,
But ne're the leſſe I am ſlaine.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis not o'this ſide?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: No Sir, I thinke it be not.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nor o' this ſide,
Was it done with a Sword?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: A Gun, a Gun ſweet Maſter.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The devill a' bullet has been here: thou art well, man.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: No ſure, I am kill'd.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Let me ſee thy thighes, and belly,
As whole as a Fiſh for any thing I ſee yet:
Thou bleed'ſt no where.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I thinke I do not bleed Sir,
But yet I am afraid I am ſlaine.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Stand up Foole,
Thou haſt as much hurt as my naile: who ſhot thee,
A Pottle, or a Pinte?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Signiour Silvio ſhot me
In theſe clothes, taking me for you, and ſeeing
The Ladder in my hand here, which I ſtole from ye,
Thinking to have gone to the Lady my ſelfe, & have ſpoke for ye

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If he had hit ye home, he had ſerv'd ye right ſirra,
You ſawcy rogue, how poore my intent ſhowes to me,
How naked now, and fooliſh?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Are ye ſure he has not hit me,
It gave a monſtruous bounce?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You riſſe of your right ſide,
And ſaid your prayers too, you had been payed elſe:
But what need'ſt thou a Bullet when thy feare kills thee?
Sirrah, keep your own counſell for all this, you'l be hang'd elſe,
If it be knowne.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: If it be by my meanes let me;
I am glad I am not kill'd, and far more gladder
My gentleman-like humours out: I feele 'tis dangerous,
And to be a gentleman, is to be kill'd twice a week.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Keepe your ſelfe cloſe ith' Country for a while ſirra.
There's Money, walk to your friends.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: They have no Piſtolls,
Nor are no Gentlemen, that's my comfort. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I will retire too, and live private; for this Silvio
Inflam'd with nobleneſſe will be my death elſe;
And if I can forget this love that loades me,
At leaſt the danger: and now I think on't better,
I have ſome concluſions elſe invites me to it. Exit.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Rodope, and Silvio at ſeverall doores.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: NEphew.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: My deare Ant.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Would you goe by thus ſlily
And never ſee me, not once ſend in to me
Your loving Neece? ſhe that above all thoſe
I call my Kindred honour'd you, and placed you
Neareſt my heart?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I thanke you worthy Couſen,
But ſuch at this time are my occaſions—

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You ſhall not goe yet, by my faith you ſhall not,
I will not be denyd: why looke ye ſad Nephew?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I am ſeldome other: O, this blood ſits heavy:
As I walk't this way late laſt night,
In meditation of ſome things concern'd me—

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What Nephew?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Why me thought I heard a Peece, Lady,
A peece ſhot off, much about this place too,
But could not judge the cauſe, nor what it boaded,
Under the Caſtle wall.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: We heard it too,
And the Watch purſu'd it preſently, but found nothing,
Not any tract.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I am right glad to heare it:
The Ruffians ſurely, that command the night
Have found him, ſtript him: and into the River
Convey'd the body.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You looke ſtill ſadder, Nephew,
Is any thing within theſe walls to comfort ye?
Speake, and be maſter of it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ye are a right Courtier,
A great Profeſſor, but a poore performer.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Do you doubt my faith: you never found me that way
I dare well ſpeake it boldly, but a true friend.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Continue then.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Try me, and ſee who falters.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I will, and preſently: 'tis in your power
To make me the moſt bound man to your courteſie.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Let me know how, and if I faile—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Tis thus then,
Get me acceſſe to the Lady Belvidere
But for a minute, but to ſee her: your Husband now
Is ſafe at Court, I left him full employ'd there.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You have ask'd the thing without my power to grant ye,
The Law lyes on the danger: if I lov'd ye not
I would bid ye goe, and there be found, and dye for't.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I knew your love, and where there ſhew'd a danger
How far you durſt ſtep for me: give me a true friend,
That where occaſion is to doe a benefit
Aymes at the end, and not the rubs before it;
I was a foole to aske ye this, a more foole
To thinke a woman had ſo much noble nature
To entertaine a ſecret of this burthen;
Ye had beſt to tell the Dutcheſſe I perſwaded ye,
That's a fine courſe, and one will win ye credit;
Forget the name of Couſen, blot my blood out,
And ſo you raiſe your ſelfe, let me grow ſhorter.
A woman friend? he that beleeves that weakneſſe
Steeres in a ſtormy night without a Compaſſe.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What is't I durſt not do might not impeach ye?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Why this ye dare not do, ye dare not thinke of.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: 'Tis a maine hazard.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: If it were not ſo
I would not come to you to ſeeke a favour.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You will loſe your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The loſſe ends with my ſelfe then.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: You will but ſee her?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Onely looke upon her.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Not ſtay?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Preſcribe your time.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Not traffique with her
In any cloſe diſhonourable actions?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Stand you your ſelfe by.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: I will venture for ye,
Becauſe ye ſhall be ſure I am a touch'd friend,
Ile bring her to ye: come walke, you know the Garden,
And take this key to open the little Poſterne,
There ſtand no guards.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I ſhall ſoone finde it Couſen. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: Is the Captaine come home?

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: No, who commands the Guard to night?

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: I thinke Petruchio.

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: What's the Word?

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: None knowes yet.

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: I would this Lady were married out oth' way once,
Or out of our cuſtodies; I wiſh they wold take in more com||panies,
For I am ſure we feel her in our duties ſhrewdly.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: 'Tis not her fault I warrant ye, ſhe is ready for't,
And that's the plague, when they grow ripe for marriage
They muſt be ſlipt like Hawkes.

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: Give me a meane wench,
No State doubt lyes on her, ſhe is alwaies ready.

sp.speaker: 1 Sol.
sp.l: Come to the Guard, 'tis late, and ſure the Captaine
Can not be long away.

sp.speaker: 2 Sol.
sp.l: I have watch'd theſe three nights,
To morrow they may keep me tame for nothing. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Silvio, Belvidere, and Rodope with a light.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: This is the place I think; what Light is that there?
The Lady and my Couſen?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is this the Garden?

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O my bleſſed Miſtris,
Saint of my ſoule.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Speake ſoftly: take me to ye,
O Silvio I am thine, thine ever Silvio.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Is this your promiſe Sir? Lady your honour?
I am undone if this be ſeene, diſgrac'd,
Fallen under all diſcredit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Do you love ſtill?
Deere, do you keepe your old faith?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ever Lady;
And when that failes me, all that's good forſake me.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Do not you ſhame? Madam, I muſt not ſuffer this,
I will not ſuffer it; men call you vertuous,
What do you meane to loſe your ſelfe thus? Silvio
I charge thee get away, charge you retire ye,
Ile call the watch elſe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Call all the world to ſee us,
We live in one anothers happineſſe,
And ſo will die.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Here will I hang for ever.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: As ye reſpect me, as hereafter Madam
You would enjoy his love—nothing prevaile with ye?
Il'e try my ſtrength then; get thee gone thou villain,
Thou Promiſe-breaker.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I am tide, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Ile ring the Bell then.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Ring it to death, I am fixt here.

div.stage: Enter Bartello, two Souldiers with lights.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: I ſaw a light over the Garden walke,
Hard by the Ladies Chamber, here's ſome knavery
As I live, I ſaw it twice.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: The Guard, the Guard there;
I muſt not ſuffer this, it is too miſchievous.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Light up the torch, I fear'd this, ha? young Silvio?
How got he in?

sp.speaker: 1. Sold.
sp.l: The Divell brought him in ſure
He came not by us.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: My wife between 'em buſling?
Guard, pull him off.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: Now, now, ye feele the miſery.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: You, Madam, at an houre ſo far undecent?
Death, O my ſoule! this is a foule fault in ye,
Your mothers care abuſd too, light's to her Chamber,
I am ſorry to ſee this.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Farewell my Sylvio,
And let no danger ſink thee.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Nor death Lady. Exit. Bell. Rod.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Are ye ſo hot? I ſhall prepare ye Phiſick
Will purge ye finely, neatly; you are too fiery,
Think of your prayers, Sir, and you have not forgot 'em;
Can ye fly i'th ayre, or creepe ye in at key-holes?
I have a gyn will catch ye though you conjur'd:
Take him to Guard to night, to ſtrong and ſure Guard;
Ile back to'th Dutcheſſe preſently: no leſſe ſport ſerve ye,
Then the Heire to a Dukedom? play at puſh-pin there Sir?
It was well aim'd, but plague upon't, you ſhot ſhort,
And that will loſe your game.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I know the loſſe then. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Now, in this habit may I ſafely ſee
How my incenſed friend carries my murther,
Who little I imagin'd had been wrought
To ſuch a height of rage; and much I grieve now
Mine owne blinde paſſion had ſo maſter'd me,
I could not ſee his love, for ſure he loves her,
And on a nobler ground then I pretended.
It muſt be ſo, it is ſo; what Penurio,
My ſhotten friend, what winde blew you?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Faith 'tis true,
Any ſtrong winde will blow me like a feather,
I am all Ayre, nothing of earth within me,
Nor have not had this moneth, but that good Dinner
Your Worſhip gave me yeſterday, that ſtaies by me,
And gives me ballaſſe, elſe the Sun would draw me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But do's my Miſtris ſpeake ſtill of me?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes Sir,
And in her ſleep, that makes my Maſter mad too,
And turne and fart for anger.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Art ſure ſhe ſaw me?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: She ſaw ye at a window.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt true,
In ſuch a place I ſaw a Gentlewoman,
A young, ſweet hanſome woman.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: That's ſhe, that's ſhe Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And well ſhe view'd me, I view'd her.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Still ſhe Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: At laſt ſhe bluſh'd, and then look't off.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: That bluſh Sir,
If you can read it truly—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But didſt thou tell her,
Or didſt thou foole me, thou knew'ſt ſuch a one?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I told her, and I told her ſuch a ſweet tale—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But did ſhe heare thee?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: With a thouſand eares Sir,
And ſwallow'd what I ſaid as greedily,
As great-bellyed women do Cherries, ſtones and all Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Methinkes ſhe ſhould not love thy Maſter?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Hang him Pilcher,
There's nothing loves him: his owne Cat cannot endure him,
She had better lye with a Beare, for he is ſo hairie,
That a tame warren of flyes frisk round about him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And wilt thou worke ſtill?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Like a Miner for ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And get acceſſe.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Or conjure you together,
'Tis her deſire to meet: ſhe is poyſon'd with him,
And till ſhe take a ſweet freſh ayre, that's you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: There's money for thee: thou art a precious Varlet,
Be fat, be fat, and blow thy Maſter backward.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Blow you my Miſtris Sir, as flat as a flounder,
Then blow her up againe as Butchers blow their Veales;
If ſhe dye upon the ſame
Bury her, bury her in Gods name.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Thou art a merry knave: by this hand ile feed thee,
Till thou crack'ſt at both ends, if thou dar'ſt do this
Thou ſhalt eat no fantaſticall Porredge,
Nor lick the diſh where oyle was yeſterday,
Duſt, and dead flyes to day; Capons, fat Capons—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: O hearty ſound.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Cramb'd full of itching Oyſters.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Will ye have the Dutcheſſe?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And Lobſters big as Gauntlets,
Thou ſhalt deſpiſe baſe Beefe.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I do deſpiſe it,
And now me thinkes I feele a Tart come ſliding.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Leaping into thy mouth: but firſt deale faithfully.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: When will ye come?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: To morrow.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Ile attend ye,
For then my Maſter will be out in buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What newes abroad?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: 'Mas as I was comming to you,
I heard that Signiour Silvio, a good Gentleman,
Many a good meale I have eaten with him—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What of him?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Was this day to be Arraigned before the Ducheſſe,
But why I could not heare.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Silvio arraign'd?
Go, get ye gone, and thinke of me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I fly Sir. Exit Pen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Arraign'd? for what? for my ſuppoſed death? no,
That cannot be ſure, there's no rumour of it,
Be it what it will, I will be there and ſee it,
And if my help will bring him off he has it. Exit.

div.head: Scaena Quinta.
div.stage: Enter Ducheſſe, Lords, Silvio priſoner, Belvidere, Bartello, Rodope, Clerke, Counſellours, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Read the Edict laſt made,
Keepe ſilence there.

body.p: If any man of what condition ſoever, and a ſubject, after the publiſhing of this Edict, ſhall without ſpeciall Licence from the great Ducheſſe, attempt or buy, offer, or make an attempt, to ſolicite the love of the Princeſſe Bel|videre, the perſon ſo offending ſhall forfeit his life.

sp.speaker: Counſellour.
sp.l: The reaſon why my Royall Miſtris here
In her laſt Treaty with Siennas Duke,
Promis'd her beauteous Daughter there in marriage,
The Duke of Millaine, rivall in this fortune,
Un-nobly ſought by practiſe to betray her;
Which found, and croſs'd, the Cittadell receiv'd her
There to ſecure her Mothers word; the laſt cauſe
So many Gentlemen of late enamour'd
On this moſt beauteous Princeſſe, and not brooking
One more then other, to deſerve a favour,
Blood has been ſpilt, many brave ſpirits loſt,
And more unleſſe ſhe had been kept cloſe from their violence
Had like to have followed: therefore for due prevention
Of all ſuch hazards and unnoble actions,
This laſt Edict was publiſh'd, which thou Silvio
Like a falſe man, a bad man, and a Traitor
Haſt rent a peeces, and contemn'd; for which cauſe
Thou ſtandeſt a guilty man here now. Ent. Claudio.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.l: Speak Silvio,
What canſt thou ſay to avoyd the hand of Juſtice?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Nothing, but I confeſſe, ſubmit, & lay my head to it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Have ye no eyes my Lords, no underſtandings?
The Gentleman will caſt himſelfe away,
Caſt himſelfe wilfully: are you, or you guilty?
No more is he, no more taint ſticks upon him:
I drew him thether, 'twas my way betray'd him,
I got the entrance kept, I entertain'd him,
I hid the danger from him, forced him to me,
Poore gentle ſoule, he's in no part tranſgreſſing,
I wrot unto him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Do not wrong that honour,
Caſt not upon that pureneſſe theſe aſperſions,
By Heaven it was my love, my violence,
My life muſt anſwer it: I broke in to her,
Tempted the Law, ſollicited unjuſtly.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: As there is truth in Heaven I was the firſt cauſe,
How could this man have come to me, left naked
Without my counſell and proviſion?
What hower could he finde out to paſſe the Watchs,
But I muſt make it ſure firſt? Reverend Judges,
Be not abus'd, nor let an innocent life lye
Upon your ſhaking Conſcience; I did it,
My love the maine wheele that ſet him a going:
His motion but compell'd.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Can ye beleeve this,
And know with what a modeſty and whiteneſſe
Her life was ever ranck'd? Can you beleeve this
And ſee me here before ye young, and wilfull?
Apt to what danger Love dares thruſt me on,
And where Law ſtops my way, apt to contemne it?
If I were baſhfull, old, or dull, and ſleepy
In Loves allarmes, a woman might awake me,
Direct, and clew me out the way to happineſſe:
But I like fire, kindled with that bright beauty,
Catch hold of all occaſions, and run through 'em.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I charge ye as your honeſt ſoules will anſwer it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I charge ye, as you are the friends to vertue,
That has no patterne living but this Lady.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Let not his blood—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Let not her wilfulneſſe—
For then you act a ſcene Hell will rejoyce at.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He is cleare.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: She is as white in this as infants.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The god of Love protect your cauſe, and help ye,
Two nobler peeces of affection
Theſe eyes ne're look'd on, if ſuch goodneſſe periſh,
Let never true hearts meet againe, but break. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: A ſtrange example of ſtrong love, a rare one.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: Madam, we know not what to ſay to think on.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe it ſtrikes me tender too,
Searches my Mothers heart: you found 'em there?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yes certaine Madam.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: And ſo linked together?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: As they had been one peece of Alablaſter.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Nothing diſhonourable?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: So let my ſoule have happineſſe,
As that thought yet durſt never ſeeke this boſome.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: What ſhall I do? 'has broke my law, abus'd me,
Faine would I know the truth, either confeſſe it,
And let me underſtand the maine offender,
Or both ſhall feele the torture.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Are ye a Mother?
The Mother of ſo ſweet a Roſe as this is?
So pure a Flower? and dare ye loſe that nature?
Dare ye take to your ſelfe ſo great a wickedneſſe,
(O holy Heaven) of thinking what may ruine
This goodly building? this temple where the gods dwell?
Give me a thouſand tortures, I deſerve 'em,
And ſhew me death in all the ſhapes imagin'd.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No death but I will anſwer it, meet it, ſeeke it;
No torture but ile laugh upon't, and kiſſe it.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: This is no way.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: They ſay no more for certaine
Then their ſtrong hearts will ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I have bethought me;
No Lords, although I have a Childe offending,
Nature dares not forget ſhe is a Childe ſtill;
Till now I never look'd on love imperious:
I have bethought me of a way to breake ye,
To ſeparate, though not your loves your bodies:
Silvio attend, ile be your Judge my ſelfe now,
The ſentence of your death (becauſe my Daughter
Will beare an equall part in your afflictions)
I take away and pardon: this remaines then
An eaſie, and a gentle puniſhment,
And this ſhall be fulfill'd: becauſe unnobly
You have ſought the love, and marriage of a Princeſſe,
The abſolute and ſole Heire of this Dukedome,
By that meanes as we muſt imagine ſtrongly,
To plant your ſelfe into this Rule hereafter,
We here pronounce ye a man baniſh'd from us.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: For ever baniſh'd Lady?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Yet more mercy,
But for a yeare: and then againe in this place
To make your full appearance: yet more pitty,
If in that time you can abſolve a queſtion,
Writ down within this ſcrowle, abſolve it rightly,
This Lady is your wife, and ſhall live with ye;
If not, you looſe your head.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I take this honour,
And humbly kiſſe thoſe Royall hands.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Receive it: Bartello, to your old guard take the Princeſſe,
And ſo the Court break up.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Farewell to all,
And to that ſpotleſſe heart my endleſſe ſervice. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.l: What will this prove?

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.l: Ile tell you a yeare hence, Sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Are you pleas'd now? have I not wrought this wonder

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Rarely Penurio.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Cloſe, cloſe then, and work wax.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I am ſtudying for thee
A dinner, that ſhall victuall thee for ten yeare.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Do you heare Miſtris?
You know what a dundier whelp my Maſter is,
I need not preach to ye, how unfit and wanting
To give a woman ſatisfaction:
How he ſtinks, and ſnores, a Bull's a better bed-fellow;
And for his love never let that deceive ye.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Nay ſure he loves me not.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: If he could coyne ye,
Or turne ye into mettle much might be then;
He loves not any thing but what is traffique:
I have heard him ſweare he would ſell ye to the grand Signior.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: The Turk.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The very Turke, and how they would uſe ye.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Ile fit him fort: the Turke?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I know the price too:
Now ye have time to pay him, pay him home Miſtris;
Pay him o'th pate, clout him for all his curteſies;
Here's one that daunces in your eyes, young delicate
To work this vengeance; if ye let it ſlip now,
There is no pittying of ye, od's precious, Miſtris,
Were I his wife, I would ſo mall his Mazard,
'Tis charity, meere charity, pure charity,
Are you the firſt? has it not been from Eves time,
Women would have their ſafe revenges this way?
And good, and gracious women, excellent women;
Is't not a handſome Gentleman? a ſweet Gentleman?
View him from head to foot, a compleat Gentleman;
When can ye hope the like againe? I leave ye,
And my revenge too, with ye; I know my Office,
Ile not be farre off, be not long a fumbling,
When danger ſhall appeare, Ile give the larme. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: You are welcome Sir, and would it were my fortune
To afford a Gentleman of your faire ſeeming,
A freer entertainment then this houſe has,
You partly know Sir.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Know, and pitty Lady,
Such ſweetneſſe in the bud, ſhould be ſo blaſted;
Dare you make me your Servant?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Dare you make Sir,
That ſervice worthy of a womans favour
By conſtancy and goodneſſe?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Here I ſweare to ye,
By the unvalued love I beare this beauty,
(And kiſſe the Book too) never to be recreant,
To honour ye, to truly love, and ſerve ye,
My youth to wait upon ye, what my wealth has.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: O make me not ſo poore, to ſell affection,
Thoſe bought love's Sir, weare faſter then the moneys;
A handſome Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A moſt delicate ſweet one,
Let my truth Purchaſe then.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I ſhould firſt try it,
But you may happily.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You ſhall not doubt me,
I hope ſhe loves me; when I prove falſe ſhame take me;
Will ye believe a little?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I feare, too much, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And will ye love a little?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: That ſhould be your part.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Thus I begin then, thus and thus.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: A good beginning,
We have a Proverbe ſaies, makes a good ending.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Say ye ſo? 'tis well infer'd.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Good Sir, your patience:
Me thinks I have ventur'd now, like a weak Bark
Upon a broken billow, that will ſwallow me,
Upon a rough ſea of ſuſpitions,
Stuck round with ieallous rocks.

sp.speaker: Pen. within.
sp.l: A hem, a hem there.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: This is my man; my feares too ſoone have found me,
Now what's the newes?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A pox of yonder old Rigell,
The Captaine, the old Captaine.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: What old Captaine?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Captaine couragious yonder of the Caſtle,
Captaine dondeigo, old Bartello.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: He's comming in:
'Twould vex the Divell, that ſuch an old Potgun as this,
That can make no ſport, ſhould hinder them that can do it.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I would not have him ſee the Gentleman
For all the world, my credit were undone then.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Shall I fling a piſſe-pot on's head as he comes in,
And take him into'th Kitchin, there to dry him.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: That will not do; and he is ſo humerous too
He will come in.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: One much troubles me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: And can do nothing, cannot eat.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Your ſight now,
Out of a driveling dotage he beares to me,
May make him tell my husband, and undo me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What would ye have me do?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: But for a while Sir,
Step here behind this hanging, preſently
I'le anſwer him, and then.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I will obey ye.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Where's my rich Jeweller? I have ſtones to ſet.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: He is abroad, and ſure Sir.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Ther's for your ſervice:
Wher's the faire Lady? all alone ſweet beauty?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: She's never much alone Sir, that's acquainted
With ſuch companions as good honeſt thoughts are.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ile ſit down by thee, and ile kiſſe thy hand too,
And in thine eare ſweare by my life I love thee.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Ye are a merry Captaine.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And a mad one, Lady;
By th'mas thou haſt goodly eyes, excellent eyes, wench,
Ye twinkling rogue, look what thy Captain brings thee,
Thou muſt needs love me, love me heartily,
Hug me, and love me, hug me cloſe.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Fye Captaine.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Nay, I have ſtrength, and I can ſtraine ye ſirrah,
And vault into my ſeat as nimbly, little one.
As any of your ſmooth chinn'd boyes in Florence,
I muſt needs commit a little folly with ye,
Ile not be long, a brideling caſe, and away wench;
The hobnaile thy husband's as fitly out o'th way now.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Do you think he keeps a bawdy houſe?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That's all one.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Or did you ever ſee that lightneſſe in my carriage,
That you might promiſe to your ſelf —

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Away foole,
A good turn's a good turne; I am an honeſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: You have a handſome wife, a vertuous Gentlewo|man.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They are not for this time o'th yeer.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: A Lady,
That ever bore that great reſpect to you,
That noble conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That's more then I know.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: O Miſtris, ye are undone, my Maſter's coming.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Coming hard by here.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Plague Conſume the Raſcall,
Shall I make petty-patties of him?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Now what love Sir?
Feare of your comming made him jealous firſt;
Your finding here, will make him mad and deſperate,
And what in that wilde mood he will execute—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I can think of nothing, I have no wit left me,
Certaine my heads a muſtard-pot.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I have thought Sir.
And if you'l pleaſe to put in execution
What I conceive—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'le do it, tell it quickly.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Draw your Sword quickly, and go down inrag'd,
As if you had purſu'd ſome foe up hither,
And grumble to your ſelf extremely, terribly,
But not a word to him, and ſo paſſe by him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ile do it perfectly.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Stand you ſtill good Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Raſcall, ſlave, villaine, take a houſe ſo poorely,
After thou haſt wrong'd a Gentleman, a Souldier,
Baſe Poultroon boy, you will forſake your neaſt ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: The matter, good ſweet Captain?

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Run-away rogue,
And take a houſe to cover thy baſe cowardize,
Ile whip ye, Ile ſo ſcourge ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Mercy upon me,
What's all this matter wife?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Did you meet the mad man?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I never ſaw the Captain ſo provok't yet.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: O he's a Devill ſure, a moſt bloody devill,
He follow'd a young Gentleman, his ſword drawne,
With ſuch a fury, how I ſhake to think on't,
And foyn'd, and flaſh't at him, and ſwore he'd kill him,
Drove him up hither, follow'd him ſtill bloodily,
And if I had not hid him, ſure had ſlaine him;
A mercileſſe old man.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Moſt vertuous Lady,
Even as the giver of my life, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This fellow muſt not ſtay here, he is too hanſom;
He is gone Sir, and you may paſſe now with all ſecurity,
Ile be your guide my ſelfe, and ſuch a way
Ile lead ye, none ſhall croſſe, nor none ſhall know ye.
The doore's left open Sirrah, ile ſtarve you for this trick,
Ile make thee faſt o' Sondayes; and for you Lady,
Ile have your lodgings farther off, and cloſer,
Ile have no ſtreet lights to you; will you go Sir?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I thank ye Sir; the Devill take this fortune;
And once more all my ſervice to your goodneſſe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Now could I eat my very arms for madneſſe,
Croſſ'd in the nick o'th matter? vengeance take it,
And that old Cavalier that ſpoil'd our Cock-fight;
Ile lay the next plot ſurer.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I am glad and ſorry;
Glad, that I got ſo fairely off ſuſpition;
Sorry I loſt my new lov'd friend.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Not loſt Miſtris;
Ile conjure once againe to raiſe that ſpirit;
In, and looke ſoberly upon the matter,
Wee'l ring him one peale more, and if that fall,
The Devill take the clappers, bells, and all. Exeunt

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: NOw, Rhodope, How do you finde my daughter?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Madam, I finde her now what you would have her,
What the State wiſhes her; I urg'd her fault to her,
Open'd her eyes, and made her ſee the miſchiefe
She was running with a headlong will into,
Made her ſtait at her folly, ſhake and tremble,
At the meere memory of ſuch an ignorance,
She now contemnes his love, hates his remembrance,
Cannot endure to heare the name of Silvio;
His perſon ſpits at.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I am glad to heare this.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: And humbly now to your will, your care, Madam,
Bends her affections, bowes her beſt obedience;
Syennas Duke, with new eyes now ſhe looks on,
And with a Princely love, ſit for his perſon,
Returnes that happineſſe and joy he look't for;
The generall good of both the neighbour Dukedoms,
Not any private end, or raſh affection
She aims at now: hearing the Duke ariv'd too,
(To whom ſhe owes all honour, and all ſervice,)
She charg'd me kneele thus at your Graces feet,
And not to riſe without a generall pardon.

sp.speaker: Du h.
sp.l: She has it, and my love againe, my old love,
And with more tenderneſſe I meet this penitence,
Then if ſhe ne're had ſtarted from her honour;
I thank ye Rhodopc, am bound to thank ye,
And dayly to remember this great ſervice,
This honeſt faithfull ſervice; go in peace,
And by this Ring, delivered to Bartello,
Let her enjoy our favour, and her liberty,
And preſently to this place, with all honour,
See her conducted.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Your Grace has made me happy. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: Syennas noble Duke, craves his admittance.

div.stage: Enter Duke of Syenna with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Go, wait upon his Grace; fair Sir, you are welcome,
Welcome to her ever admir'd your vertues:
And now, me thinks, my Court looks true nobly;
You have taken too much pains, Sir.

sp.speaker: Syen.
sp.l: Royall Lady,
To wait upon your Grace is but my ſervice.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Keep that Sir, for the Saint ye have vow'd it to.

sp.speaker: Syen.
sp.l: I keep a life for her: Since your Grace pleaſes
To jump ſo happily into the matter,
I come indeed to claime your royall promiſe,
The beauteous Belvidere in marriage,
I come to tender her my youth, my fortune,
My everlaſting love.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: You are like to win Sir:
All is forgot, forgiven too; no ſadneſſe
My good Childe, you have the ſame heart ſtill here,
The Duke of Syenna, Childe, pray uſe him nobly.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: An Angell beauty.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Your Grace is fairely welcome,
And what in modeſty a bluſhing maid may
Wiſh to a Gentleman of your great goodneſſe;
But wiſhes are too poore a pay for Princes.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: You have made me richer then all States and Titles,
One kiſſe of this white hand's above all honours,
My faith deare Lady, and my fruitfull ſervice,
My duteous zeale—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Your Grace is a great Maſter,
And ſpeake too powerfully to be reſiſted:
Once more you are welcome Sir, to me you are welcome,
To her that honoures ye; I could ſay more Sir,
But in anothers tongue 'twere better ſpoken,

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: As wiſe as faire, you have made your Servant happy;
I never ſaw ſo rich a Mine of ſweetneſſe.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Will your Grace pleaſe, after your painfull journy
To take ſome reſt? Are the Dukes Lodgings ready?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: All Madam.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Then wait upon his Grace, all, and to morrow Sir
We'l ſhew ye in what high eſteeme we hold ye,
Till then a faire repoſe.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: My faireſt ſervice Exit Duke, &c.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: You have ſo honour'd me, my deareſt Daughter,
So truly pleas'd me in this entertainment,
I meane your loving carriage to Syenna,
That both for ever I forget all treſpaſſes,
And to ſecure you next of my full favour,
Aske what you will within my power to grant ye,
Aske freely: and if I forget my promiſe—
Aske confidently.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You are too royall to me,
To me that have ſo fooliſhly tranſgreſs'd you,
So like a Girle, ſo far forgot my vertue,
Which now appeares as baſe and ugly to me,
As did his Dream, that thought he was in Paradice,
Awak'd and ſaw the Devill; how was I wander'd?
With what eyes could I look upon that poore, that courſe thing,
That wretched thing call'd Silvio? that (now) deſpis'd thing?
And loſe an object of that gracefull ſweetneſſe,
That god-like preſence as Syenna is?
Darkneſſe, and cheerfull day had not ſuch difference:
But I muſt ever bleſſe your care, your wiſedome,
That led me from this labirinth of folly,
How had I ſunk elſe? what example given?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Prethee no more, and as thou art my beſt one,
Aske ſomething that may equall ſuch a goodneſſe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why did ye let him go ſo ſlightly from ye,
More like a man in triumph, then condemn'd?
Why did ye make his pennance but a queſtion,
A riddle, every idle wit unlocks.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: 'Tis not ſo,
Nor do not feare it ſo: he will not finde it,
I have given that (unleſſe my ſelfe diſcover it)
Will coſt his head.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis ſubject to conſtruction?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: That it is too.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It may be then abſolv'd,
And then are we both ſcorn'd and laugh'd at, Madam;
Beſide the promiſe you have ty'd upon it,
Which you muſt never keepe.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I never meant it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: For heaven ſake let me know it, 'tis my Suit to ye,
The Boone you would have me aske; let me but ſee it,
That if there be a way to make't ſo ſtrong,
No wit nor powerfull reaſon can run through it,
For my diſgrace, I may beg of heaven to grant it.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Feare not, it has been put to ſharper judgements
Then ere he ſhall arrive at: my deare Father,
That was as fiery in his underſtanding,
And ready in his wit as any living,
Had it two yeares; and ſtudied it, yet loſt it:
This night ye are my Bed-fellow, there Daughter
Into your boſome ile commit this ſecret,
And there we'l both take counſell.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I ſhall finde
Some trick I hope too ſtrong yet for his minde. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Methinks I am batten'd well of late, growne luſty,
Fat, high, and kicking, thankes to the bounteous Rugio;
And now, methinkes I ſcorne theſe poore repaſts,
Cheeſe parings, and the ſtinking tongues of Pilchers;
But why ſhould I remember theſe? they are odious,
They are odious in mine eyes; the full fat diſh now,
The bearing diſh is that I reverence,
The diſh an able Serving-man ſweats under,
And bends ith' hams, as if the houſe hung on him,
That diſh is the diſh: hang your bladder Bankets,
Or halfe a dozen of Turnop, and two Muſhrumps,
Theſe when they breed their beſt, hatch but two Belches;
The ſtate of a fat Turkey, the decorum
He marches in with, all the traine and circumſtance;
'Tis ſuch a matter, ſuch a glorious matter,
And then his ſauce, with Orenges and Onions,
And he diſplay'd in all parts, for ſuch a diſh now,
And at my need I would betray my father,
And for a roaſted Conger, all my Country.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What my friend Lean-gut, how do's thy beauteous Miſtris?
And where's your Maſter Sirra? where's that horn-pipe?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: My Miſtris Sir, do's as a poore wrong'd Gentlewoman,
Too much heaven knows oppreſt with injuries,
May do and live.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Is the old foole ſtill jealous?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: As old fooles are, and will be ſtill the ſame Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He muſt have cauſe: he muſt have cauſe.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: 'Tis true Sir,
And would he had with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He ſhall have.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: For then he had Salt to his Saffron Porredge.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why do not I ſee thee ſometime? why thou ſtarv'd raſcal?
Why do not ye come to me, you precius bow-caſe?
I keepe good meat at home, good ſtore:

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes Sir,
I will not faile ye all next weeke.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou art welcome,
I have a ſecret I would faine impart to thee,
But thou art ſo thin the wind will blow it from thee,
Or men will read it through thee.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Wrapt up in beefe Sir,
In good groſſe beefe, let all the world looke on me,
The Engliſh have that trick to keep intelligence.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A witty knave, firſt there's to tye your tongue up,

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Dumbe as a Dog Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Next, hark in your eare. Sirra.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Well, very well, excellent well: 'tis done Sir,
Say no more to me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Say and hold.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: 'Tis done Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: As thou lov'ſt butter'd eggs, ſweare.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Let me kiſſe the Booke firſt,
But here's my hand, brave Captaine.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Looke ye hold, ſirra. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: O the moſt precious vanity of this world
When ſuch dry Neatſ-tongues muſt be ſok'd and larded
With young fat ſupple wenches? O the Devill,
What can he do, he cannot ſuck an egge off
But his back's looſe ith' hilts: go thy waies Captaine,
Well may thy Warlike name work Miracles,
But if e're thy founder'd courſer win match more,
Or ſtand right but one traine—

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: Now Signiour Shadow,
What art thou thinking of, how to rob thy Maſter?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Of his good deeds? the Thief that undetakes that
Muſt have a hook will poze all Hell to hammer:
Have ye dined Gentlemen, or do you purpoſe?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Dined, two long houres ago.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Pray ye take me with ye.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: To ſupper do'ſt thou meane?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: To any thing
That has the ſmell of meat in't: tell me true, Gentlemen,
Are not you three now going to be ſinfull,
To jeabard a joynt, or ſo? I have found your faces,
And ſee whore written in your eyes.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: A parlous Raſcall,
Thou art much upon the matter.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Have a care Gentlemen,
'Tis a ſore age, very ſore age, lewd age,
And women now are like old Knights adventures,
Full of inchanted flames, and dangerous.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent,
sp.l: Where the moſt danger is, there's moſt honour.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I grant ye, honour moſt conſiſts in ſufferance,
And by that rule you three ſhould be moſt honourable.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: A ſubtle Rogue: but canſt thou tell Penurio
Where we might light upon—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A learned Surgeon?

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: Pox take ye foole; I meane good wholſome wenches.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: 'Faith wholſome women will but ſpoyle ye too,
For you are ſo us'd to ſnap-haunces: But take my counſell,
Take fat old women, fat, and five and fifty,
The Dog-dayes are come in.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Take fat old women?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The fatter and the older, ſtill the better,
You do not know the pleaſure of an old Dame,
A fat old Dame, you do not know the knack on't:
They are like our Country grotes, as coole as Chriſtmas,
And ſure ith' keeles.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Hang him ſtarv'd foole, he mocks us.

sp.speaker: 3. Gent.
sp.l: Penurio, thou know'ſt all the hanſome wenches?
What ſhall I give thee for a Merchants wife now?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I take no money Gentlemen, that's baſe,
I trade in meat, a Merchants wife will coſt ye
A glorious Capon, a great ſhoulder of Mutton,
And a Tart as big as a Conjurers circle.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: That's cheap enough.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: And what a Haberdaſhers?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Worſe meat will ſerve for her: a great Gooſe Pye,
But you muſt ſend it out oth' Country to me,
It will not do elſe: with a peece of Bacon,
And if you can a pot of Butter with it.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Now do I ayme at horſe-fleſh: what a Parſons?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A tithe Pig has no fellow, if I fetch her,
If ſhe be Puritane, Plumb-porridge do's it,
And a fat loyne of Veale well ſawc'd and roſted.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Wee'l meet one night, and thou ſhalt have all theſe,
O' that condition we may have the wenches,
A dainty raſcall.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: When your ſtomacks ſerve ye,
(For mine is ever ready) ile ſupply ye.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: Farewell, and there's to fill thy paunch.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Brave Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Hold ſirrah, there.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Any young wench ith' Towne Sir.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: It ſhall go round. Exit Gent.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Moſt honourable Gentlemen,
All theſe are Courtiers, but they are meere Coxcombs,
And only for a wench, their purſes open,
Nor have they ſo much judgement left to chuſe her;
If e're they call upon me ile ſo fit 'em,
I have a pack of wry-mouth'd mackrell Ladies,
Stinke like a ſtanding ditch, and thoſe deare Damſels;
But I forgot my buſineſſe, I thank ye Mounſieurs,
I have a thouſand whimſies in my braines now. Exit.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter (to a Banket) Duches, Syenna, Lords, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Your Grace ſhall now perceive how much we honor ye
And in what deare regard we hold your friendſhip
Will you ſit Sir, and grace this homely Banquet?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Madam, to your poor friend you are too magnificent.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.l: To the Dukes health, and all the joyes I wiſh him,
Let no man miſſe this cup: have we no Muſick?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Your noble favours ſtill you heap upon me,
But where's my vertuous Miſtris, ſuch a Feaſt,
And not her ſparkling beauty here to bleſſe it?
Me thinkes it ſhould not be, it ſhewes not fully.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Young Ladies Sir, are long, and curious
In putting on their trims, forget how day goes,
And then 'tis their good morrow when they are ready:
Go ſome and call her, and wait upon her hither,
Tell her the Duke and I deſire her company:
I warrant ye, a hundred dreſſings now
She has ſurvey'd, this, and that faſhion look'd on,
For Ruffs and Gowns; caſt this away, theſe Jewels
Suited to theſe and theſe knots: o' my life Sir,
She feares your curious eye will ſoone diſcover elſe:
Why ſtand ye ſtill, why gape ye on one another?
Did I not bid ye go and tell my Daughter?
Are ye nayled here? nor ſtir? nor ſpeake? who am I,
And who are you?

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: Pardon me, gracious Lady,
The feare to tell you that you would not hear of
Makes us all dumb, the Princeſſe is gone, Madam.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Gone? whither gone? ſome wiſer fellow anſwer me.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: We ſought the Court all over, and beleeve Lady,
No newes of where ſhe is, nor how convey'd hence.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: It cannot be, it muſt not be.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: 'Tis true Madam,
No roome in all the Court but we ſearch'd through it,
Her women found her want firſt, and they cry'd to us.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Gone? ſtolne away? I am abus'd, diſhonour'd.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: 'Tis I that am abus'd, 'tis I diſhonour'd,
Is this your welcome, this your favour to me?
To foyſt a trick upon me, this trick too,
To cheat me of my love? Am I not worthy?
Or ſince I was your Gueſt, am I growne odious?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Your Grace miſtakes me, as I have a life, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: And I another, I will never beare this,
Never endure this dor.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: But heare me patiently.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Give me my love.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: As ſoone as care can find her,
And all care ſhall be uſed.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: And all my care too,
To be reveng'd; I ſmell the trick, 'tis too ranke,
Fie, how it ſmells oth' Mother.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: You wrong me, Duke.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: For this diſgrace ten thouſand Florentines
Shall pay their deareſt bloods, and dying curſe ye,
And ſo I turne away, your mortall enemy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.l: Since ye are ſo high and hot Sir, ye have half arm'd us,
Be carefull of the Towne, of all the Caſtles,
And ſee ſupplyes of Souldiers every where,
And Muſters for the Field, when he invites us,
For he ſhall know 'tis not high words can fright us.
My Daughter gone? has ſhe ſo finely cozen'd me?
This is for Silvio's ſake ſure, O cunning falſe one;
Publiſh a Proclamation thorough the Dukedome.
That whoſoe're can bring toth' Court young Silvio,
Alive or dead, beſide our thankes and favour,
Shall have two thouſand Duckets for his labour;
See it diſpatch'd, and ſent in haſte: O baſe one. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Iſabella, and Penurio with a Light.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Was't thou with Rugio?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes marry was I cloſely.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: And do's he ſtill remember his poore Miſtris?
Do's he deſire to ſee me?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes, and preſently:
Puts off all buſineſſe elſe, lives in that memory,
And will be here according to directions.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: But where's thy Maſter?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Where a coxcombe ſhould be,
Waiting at Court with his Jewells,
Safe for this night I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I am bound to thee.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I would ye were; as cloſe as I could tye ye,

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Thou art my beſt, my trueſt friend.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I labour,
I moyle and toyle for ye: I am your hackney.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: If ever I be able—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Steale the great Cheeſe Miſtris,
Was ſent him out oth' Country.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: That's meat, 'tis lawfull Miſtris: where's the Caſtle Cuſtard
He got at Court?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: He has lock't it in's ſtudy.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Get a warrant to ſearch for counterfeit gold.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Give me thy Candle,
Ile finde a time to be thy carefull Cater.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: And many a time Ile finde to be his Cook,
And dreſſe his Calves head to the ſweeteſt ſauce Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: To bed Penurio, go, the reſt is my charge,
Ile keep the Watch out.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Now if you ſpare him— Exit.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Peace foole,
I hope my Rugio will not faile, 'twould vexe me:
Now to my ſtring; ſo, ſure he cannot miſſe now,
And this end to my finger: ile lye downe,
For on a ſuddaine I am wondrous heavy,
'Tis very late too; if he come, and finde this,
And pull it, though it be with eaſie motion
I ſhall ſoone waken, and as ſoone be with him.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Thou ſecret friend, how am I bound to love thee,
And how to hug thee for thy private ſervice?
Thou art the Star all my ſuſpitions ſaile by,
The fixed point my wronged honour turnes to,
By thee I ſhall know all, finde all the ſubtilties
Of devilliſh women, that torment me daily:
Thou art my Conjurer, my Spell, my Spirit,
All's huſh'd and ſtill, no ſound of any ſtirring,
No tread of living thing: the Light is in ſtill,
And there's my wife, how prettily the foole lyes,
How ſweet, and handſomely, and in her clothes too,
Waiting for me upon my life; her fondneſſe
Would not admit her reſt till I came to her:
O carefull foole, why am I angry with thee?
Why do I think thou hat'ſt thy loving Husband?
I am an Aſſe, an over-doating Coxcombe,
And this ſweet ſoule the mirrour of perfection:
How admirable faire and delicate,
And how it ſtirs me, ile ſing thy ſweets a Requiem,
But will not waken thee.

body.head: Song.
body.l: O Faire ſweet face, O eyes celeſtiall bright,
Twin-ſtars in Heaven that now adorn the night;
O fruitfull lips, where Cherries ever grow,
And Damask cheeks, where all ſweet beauties blow;
O thou from head to foot divinely faire,
Cupids moſt cunning Nets made of that haire,
And as he weaves himſelfe for curious eyes,
O me, O me, I am caught my ſelfe, he cryes:
Sweet reſt ahout this ſweets and golden ſleepe,
Soft peacefull thoughts your how' rely watches keepe,
Whilſt I in wonder ſing this ſacrifice,
To beauty ſacred, and thoſe Angell-eyes.

sp.l: Now will I ſteale a kiſſe, a deare kiſſe from her,
And ſuck the Roſie breath of this bright beauty;
What a Devill is this? ty'd to her finger too?
A ſtring, a damned ſtring to give intelligence
O my lov'd key, how truly has'ſt thou ſerv'd me;
Ile follow this: ſoft, ſoft, toth' doore it goes,
And through toth' other ſide; a damned ſtring 'tis,
I am abus'd, topt, Cuckolded, fooled, jaded,
Ridden to death, to madneſſe; ſtay, this helps not:
Stay, ſtay, and now invention help me,
Ile ſit downe by her, take this from her eaſily,
And thus upon mine owne: Dog, I ſhall catch ye,
With all your cunning Sir: I ſhall light on ye,
I felt it pull ſure: yes, but wondrous ſoftly,
'Tis there againe, and harder now, have at ye:
Now and thou ſcap'ſt, the Devills thy ghoſtly father. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Sure 'twas my Husbands voyce: The ſtring is gone to,
He has found the trick on't: I am undone, betray'd,
And if he meet my friend he periſhes,
What fortune followes me, what ſpightfull fortune?
Hoa, Jaquenet.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Here Miſtris, do you call me?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Didſt thou heare no noiſe?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I heare my Maſter mad yonder,
And ſweares, and chafes—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Dar'ſt thou do one thing for me?
One thing concernes mine honour, all is loſt elſe?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Name what you will.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: It can bring but a beating,
Which I will recompence ſo largely—

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Name it.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Sit here, as if thou wert aſleep.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: When he comes in, what e're he do unto thee
(The worſt will be but beating) ſpeak not a word,
Not one word as thou loveſt me.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Ile run through it.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Ile carry away the Candle. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And I the blowes Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Have you put your light out? I ſhall ſtumble to ye,
You whore, you cunning whore, I ſhal catch your rogue to,
Has light leggs elſe: I had ſo Ferret-claw'd him:
O have I found ye? do ye play at dog-ſleep ſtill whore?
Do you think that can protect ye? yes, I will kill thee,
But firſt ile bring thy friends to view thy villanies,
Thy whoriſh villanies: and firſt ile beat thee,
Beat thee to pin-duſt, thou ſalt whore, thou varlet,
Scratch out thine eyes; ile ſpoile your tempting viſage;
Are ye ſo patient? ile put my nayles in deeper,
Is it good whoring? whoring ye baſe raſcall?
Is it good tempting men with ſtrings to ride ye?
So, ile fetch your kindred, and your friends, whore,
And ſuch a Juſtice I will act upon thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: What is he gone?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: The Devill go with him Miſtris,
Has harrowed me, plow'd land was ne're ſo harrowed:
I had the moſt ado to ſave mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Iſah.
sp.l: Has paid thee,
But ile heale all againe with good gold Jaquenet;
Has damned nayles.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: They are ten-penny nayles I think Miſtris:
Ile undertake he ſhall ſtrike 'em through an inch board.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Go up, and waſh thy ſelfe: take my Pomatum,
And now let me alone to end the Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Joq.
sp.l: You had beſt beware.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I ſhall deale ſtoutly with him,
Reach me my book, and ſee the doore made faſt wench,
And ſo good night: now to the matter politick.

sp.speaker: Lop. within
sp.l: You ſhall ſee what ſhe is, what a ſweet jewell.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Who's there, what mad-man knocks? is this an hower
And in mine husbands abſence?

sp.speaker: Lop. within.
sp.l: Will ye open?
You know my voyce ye whore, I am that husband:
Do you mark her ſubtlety? but I have paid her,
I have ſo ferk'd her face: here's the blood Gentlemen,
Ecce ſignum: I have ſpoyl'd her Goatiſh beauty,
Obſerve her how ſhe lookes now, how ſhe is painted,
O 'tis the moſt wicked'ſt whore, and the moſt treacherous-

div.stage: Enter Lopez, Bartello, Gent. and two Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here walkes my Couſen full of meditation,
Arm'd with religious thoughts.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Is this the monſter?

sp.speaker: 1 Gentlew.
sp.l: Is this the ſubject of that rage you talk't of,
That naughty woman you had pull'd a peeces?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Here's no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: 1. Gentlew.
sp.l: How have ye wrong'd this beauty?
Are not you mad my friend? what time o'th Moon is't?
Have not you Maggots in your braines?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe ſure.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Where's the ſcratch'd face ye ſpoke of, the torne garments,
And all the haire pluck'd off her head?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Beleeve me,
'Twere better far you had loſt your paire of pibbles,
Then ſhe the leaſt adornment of that ſweetneſſe.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Is not this blood?

sp.speaker: 1 Gentlew.
sp.l: This is a monſtrous folly,
A baſe abuſe.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Thus he do's ever uſe me,
And ſtickes me up a wonder, not a woman,
Nothing I do but ſubject to ſuſpition;
Nothing I can do able to content him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Lopez, you muſt not uſe this.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentlew.
sp.l: 'Twere not amiſſe Sir,
To give ye ſauce to your meat, and ſuddainly.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentlew.
sp.l: You that dare wrong a woman of her goodneſſe,
Thou have a wife, thou have a Beare ty'd to thee,
To ſcratch thy jealous itch, were all o' my minde,
I meane all women, we would ſoone disburthen ye
Of that that breeds theſe fits, theſe dog-flawes in ye,
A Sow-guelder ſhould trim ye.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A rare cure Lady,
And one as fit for him as a Thief for a halter,
You ſee this youth: will you not cry him quittance,
Body' me, I would pine, but I would pepper him,
Ile come anon, he, hang him, poore pompillion:
How like a wench bepiſt he lookes, ile come Lady:
Lopez, the Law muſt teach ye what a wife is,
A good, a vertuous wife.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Ile ne're live with him,
I crave your loves all to make knowne my cauſe,
That ſo a faire Divorce may paſſe between us,
I am weary of my life: in danger hourely.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You ſee how rude you are, I will not miſſe ye,
Unſufferable rude: ile pay him ſoundly,
You ſhould be whipt in Bedlam: ile reward him.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentlew.
sp.l: Whipping's too good.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I think I am alive ſtill,
And in my wits.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ile put a trick upon him,
And get his goods Confiſcate: you ſhall have 'em;
I will not faile at nine.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I think I am here too,
And once I would have ſworn I had taken her napping,
I think my name is Lopez.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Fie for ſhame Sir,
You ſee you have abus'd her, foulely wrong'd her,
Hung ſcandalous and courſe opinions on her,
Which now you finde but children of ſuſpition:
Aske her forgiveneſſe, ſhew a penitence,
She is my Kinſ-woman, and what ſhe ſuffers
Under ſo baſe and beaſtly jealouſies,
I will redreſſe elſe, ile ſeeke ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why, every Boy ith' Towne will piſſe upon thee.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I am ſorry for't.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentlew.
sp.l: Downe o' your marrow-bones.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Even ſorry from my heart: forgive me ſweet wife,
Here I confeſſe moſt freely I have wrong'd ye,
As freely here I beg a pardon of ye,
From this hower no debate, no croſſe ſuſpition—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: To ſhew ye Sir I underſtand a wives part,
Thus I aſſure my love, and ſeale your pardon.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentlew.
sp.l: 'Tis well done, now to bed and there confirm it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And ſo good night.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Aware relapſes, Lopez. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Now Iſabella tell me truth, and ſuddainly,
And do not juggle with me, nor diſſemble,
For as I have a life ye dye then: I am not mad,
Nor do's the Devill work upon my weakneſſe,
Tell me the trick of this, and tell me freely.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Will then that ſatisfie ye?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: If ye deale ingenuouſly.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Ile tell ye all, and tell ye true and freely,
Bartello was the end of all this jealouſie,
His often viſitations brought by you, firſt
Bred all theſe fits, and theſe ſuſpitions:
I knew your falſe key, and accordingly
I fram'd my plot, to have him take him finely,
Too poore a pennance for the wrong his wife beares,
His worthy vertuous wife: I felt it ſenſibly
When ye tooke off the ſtring, and was much pleas'd in't,
Becauſe I wiſh'd his importunate dotage paid well,
And had you ſtaid two minutes more, ye had had him.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This ſounds like truth.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Becauſe this ſhall be certaine,
Next time he comes, as long he cannot tarry,
Your ſelf ſhall ſee, and heare, his lew'd temptations.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Till then I am ſatisfied, and if this prove true,
Henceforward Miſtris of your ſelf I give ye,
And I to ſerve ye: For my luſty Captaine,
Ile make him daunce, and make him think the Devill
Clawes at his breech, and yet I will not hurt him:
Come now to bed, and prove but conſtant this way,
Ile prove the man you ever wiſhed.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: You have bleſt me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: WHat labour and what travell have I runne Through?
And through what Cities to abſolve this Riddle?
Diviners, Dreamers, Schoolemen, deep Magitians,
All have I tride, and all give ſeverall meanings,
And from all hope of any future happineſſe,
To this place am I come at length, the country,
The people ſimple, plaine, and harmleſſe witty,
Whoſe honeſt labours Heaven rewards with plenty
Of Corne, Wine, Oyle, which they againe, as thankfull,
To their new Cropps, new paſtimes celebrate,
And crowne their joyfull harveſts with new voyces;
By a rich farmer here I am entertain'd,
And rank't among the number of his Servants,
Not gueſſing what I am, but what he would have me,
Here may be ſo much wit (though much I feare it)
To undo this knotty queſtion; and would to Heaven
My fortunes had been hatch'd with theirs, as innocent,
And never knowne a pitch above their plainneſſe.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: That it is, that it is, what's this word now? this
Is a plaguy word, that it is, r. e. a. that it is, reaſon,
By your leave, Mr. Soto, by your leave, you are too quick, Sir,
Ther's a ſtrange par'lous T. hefore the reaſon,
A very tall T. which makes the word High Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: What Treaſon's that? do's this fellow underſtand Himſelfe?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Pitch will infect, ile meddle no more with this geere;
What a Devill ayles this fellow? this fooliſh fellow,
Being admitted to be one of us too,
That are the maſters of the Sports proceeding,
Thus to appeare, before me too, unmorriſſ'd?
Do you know me friend?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You are my Matters Son, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: And do you know what ſports are now in ſeaſon?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I heare there are ſome a foot.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Where are your Bells then?
Your Rings, your Ribanes, friend? & your clean Napkins?
Your noſegay in your hat, pinn'd up, am not I here?
My fathers eldeſt Son, and at this time, Sir,
I would have ye know it, though ye be ten times his ſervant,
A better man then my father far, Lord of this Harveſt, Sir,
And ſhall a man of my place want attendance?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Twas want of knowledge, Sir, not duty, bred this,
I would have made ſuit elſe for your Lordſhips ſervice.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: In ſome ſort I am ſatisfied now, mend your maners,
But thou art a melancholly fellow, veng'ance melancholly,
And that may breed a inſurrection amongſt us;
Go too, Ile lay the beſt part of two pots now
Thou art in love, and I can gueſſe with whom too,
I ſaw the wench that twir'd and twinkled at thee,
The other day; the wench that's new come hither,
The young ſmug wench.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: You know more then I feele Sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Go too, Ile be thy friend, ile ſpeak a good word for thee,
And thou ſhalt have my Lordſhips countenance to her;
May be I have had a ſnap my ſelf, may be I, may be no,
We Lords are allow'd a little more.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Tis fit Sir;
I humbly thank ye, you are too too tender of me,
But what Sir, I beſeech ye, was that paper,
Your Lordſhip was ſo ſtudiouſly Imployed in,
When ye came out a doores?

sp.speaker: Soto.
