sp.l: Thou meaneſt this paper.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: That Sir, I think.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Why, 'tis a Proclamation,
A notable piece of villany, as ever thou heard'ſt in thy life,
By mine honour it is.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: How Sir? or what concernes it?

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: It comes ye from the Ducheſſe, a plaguy wiſe woman,
To apprehend the body of one Silvio,
As arrant a Raſcall as ever piſt againſt poſt,
And this ſame Silvio, or this foreſaid raſcall,
To bring before her, live or dead; for which good ſervice
The man that brings him, has two thouſand Duckets;
Is not this notable matter now?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo indeed,
This Proclamation beares my bane about it;
Can no reſt finde me? no private place ſecure me?
But ſtill my miſeries like blood-hounds haunt me?
Unfortunate young man, which way now guides thee,
Guides thee from death? the Countrey's laid round for thee;
O Claudio, now I feele thy blood upon me,
Now it ſpeaks lowdly here, I am ſure againſt me,
Time now has found it out, and truth proclam'd it,
And Juſtice now cries out, I muſt die for it.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Haſt thou read it?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: And doſt thou know that Silvio.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I never ſaw him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I have, and know him too,
I know him as well as I know thee, and better,
And if I light upon him, for a trick he plaid me once,
A certaine kinde of dog-trick, ile ſo fiddle him,
Two thouſand Duckets, ile ſo pepper him,
And with that money ile turne Gentleman,
Worth a browne Bakers dozen of ſuch Silvio's.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: There is no ſtaying here, this rogue will know me,
And for the money ſake betray me too;
I muſt bethink me ſuddenly and ſafely.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Mine owne deare Lady, have at thy honey-comb,
Now, for the honour of our Towne, Boyes, trace ſweetly,
What a vengeance ayles this whobub? pox refuſe 'em,
Cannot they let us dance in our owne defence here?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Arme, honeſt friends, arme ſuddenly & bravely,
And with your antient reſolutions follow me;
Look how the Beacons ſhow like comets, your poor neighbours
Run maddingly affrighted through the Villages;
Syennas Duke is up, burnes all before him,
And with his ſword, makes thouſand mothers childleſſe,

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: What's this to our Morriſdancers?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: This may ſerve my turne.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Theres ne're a Duke in Chriſtendome but loves a May-game.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: At a Horſe you were alwaies ceaz'd, put your Son on him,
And arme him well i'th States name, I command ye;
And they that dare go voluntary, ſhall receive reward.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I dare go no way, Sir, this is ſtrange, Maſter Captaine,
You cannot be content to ſpoile our ſport here,
Which I do not think your Worſhip's able to anſwer,
But you muſt ſet us together by the ears, with I know not who to?
We are for the bodily part o'th dance.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Arme him ſuddenly,
This is no time to foole, I ſhall returne ye elſe,
A rebell to the Generall, State, and Ducheſſe,
And how you'l anſwer then—

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: I have no more Sons, Sir,
This is my onely boy; I beſeech ye Maſter Captain.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: I am a rank coward too, to ſay the truth, Sir,
I never had good luck at buffets neither.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Here's vorty ſhillings, ſpare the childe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Are ye a man? will ye caſt away a May-Lord?
Shall all the wenches in the Country curſe ye?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: An't pleaſe you Captaine, ile ſupply his perſon,
'Tis pitty their old cuſtome ſhould be frighted,
Let me have Horſe, and good Armes, ile ſerve willingly,
And if I ſhrink a foot of ground, Hell take me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A promiſing aſpect, face full of courage,
Ile take this man, and thank ye too.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Ther's for thee,
'Tis in a clout, but good old gold.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I thank ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Goe ſaddle my fore-horſe, put his feather on too,
Hee'l praunce it bravely, friend, he feares no Colours,
And take the Armour down, and ſee him dizin'd,

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Farewell, & if thou carrieſt thy ſelf well in this matter,
I ſay no more, but this, there muſt be more May-Lords,
And I know who are ſit.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Dance you, Ile fight, Sir,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Farewell, I am for the Captaine. Exit.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Now to this matter againe, my honeſt fellowes,
For if this go not forward, I foreſee friends,
This war will fright our neighbours out o'th villages;
Cheere up your hearts, we ſhall heare better news, boyes.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Surely, I will daunce no more, 'tis moſt ridiculous,
I finde my wives inſtructions now meere verities,
My learned wives, ſhe often hath pronounc'd to me
My ſafety Bomby, defie theſe ſports, thou art damn'd elſe,
This Beaſt of Babylon, I will never back againe,
His pace is ſure prophane, and his lewd wihies
The Sons of Hymyn, and Gymyn, in the wilderneſſe.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Fie neighbour Bomby, in your fits againe,
Your zeale ſwets, this is not carefull, neighbour,
The Hobby-Horſe, is a ſeemely Hobby-Horſe.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: And as pretty a Beaſt on's inches, though I ſay it.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: The Beaſt is an unſeemely, and a lew'd Beaſt,
And got at Rome by the Popes Coach-Horſes,
His mother was the Mare of ignorance.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Cobler, thou lyeſt, and thou wert a thouſand Coblers,
His mother was an honeſt Mare, & a Mare of good credit,
I know the Mare, and if need be, can bring witneſſe;
And in the way of honeſty I tell thee,
Scorn'd any Coach-Horſe the Pope had, thou art fooliſh,
And thy blind zeale makes thee abuſe the Beaſt.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I do defie thee, and thy foot-cloth too,
And tell thee to thy face, this prophaine riding
I feele it in my conſcience, and I dare ſpeake it,
This unedified ambling, hath brought a ſcourge upon us,
This Hobby-horſe ſincerity we liv'd in
War, and the ſword of ſlaughter: I renounce it,
And put the Beaſt off; thus, the Beaſt poluted,
And now no more ſhall hope on high Bomby,
Follow the painted Pipes of worldly pleaſures,
And with the wicked daunce the Devills meaſures;
Away thou pamper'd jade of vanity,
Stand at the Livery of lewd delights now,
And eat the provender of prickear'd folly,
My daunce ſhall be to the pipe of perſecution.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: Will you daunce no more Neighbour?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Surely no,
Carry the Beaſt to his Crib: I have renounc'd him,
And all his workes.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Shall the Hobby-horſe be forgot then?
The hopefull Hobby-horſe? ſhall he lye founder'd?
If thou do'ſt this, thou art but a caſt-away Cobler:
My anger's up, think wiſely, and think quickly,
And look upon the quondam beaſt of pleaſure,
If thou doſt this (mark me, thou ſerious Sowter)
Thou Bench-whiſtler of the old tribe of toe-peeces,
If thou do'ſt this there ſhall be no more Shooe-mending,
Every man ſhall have a ſpeciall care of his owne ſoule:
And in his pocket carry his two Confeſſors,
His Yugell, and his Nawle: if thou do'ſt this—

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: He will dance againe for certaine.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I cry out on't,
'Twas the fore-running ſin brought in thoſe Tilt-ſtaves,
They brandiſh 'gainſt the Church, the Devill calls May-poles,
Take up your Horſe againe, and girth him to ye,
And girth him handſomely good neighbour Bomby.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I ſpit at him.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Spit in the Horſe face, Cobler?
Thou out of tune-Pſalm-ſinging Slave; ſpit in his viſnomy?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I ſpit againe, and thus I riſe againſt him:
Againſt this Beaſt: that ſignifi'd deſtruction,
Fore-ſhew'd ith' falls of Monarchies.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Ith' face of him?
Spit ſuch another ſpit, by this hand Cobler
Ile make ye ſet a new peece o' your noſe there,
'Tak't up I ſay, and dance without more bidding,
And dance as you were wont: you have been excellent
And art ſtill, but for this new nicity,
And your wives learned Lectures: take up the Hobby-horſe
Come, 'tis a thing thou haſt lov'd with all thy heart Bomby
And would'ſt do ſtill but for the round-breecht Brothers:
You were not thus in the morning, tak't up I ſay,
Do not delay but do it: you know I am officer,
And I know 'tis unfit all theſe good fellowes
Should wait the cooling of your zealous porridge;
Chuſe whether you will dance, or have me execute:
Ile clap your neek ith' Stocks, and there ile make ye
Dance a whole day, and dance with theſe at night too,
You mend old Shooes well, mend your old manners better,
And ſuddenly ſee you leave off this ſincereneſſe.
This new hot batch borrowed from ſome brown Baker,
Some learned Brother, or ile ſo bait ye for't,
Take it quickly up.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I take my perſecution,
And thus I am forced a by-word to my Brethren.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Strike up, ſtrike up: ſtrike merrily.

sp.speaker: Far.
sp.l: To it roundly,
Now to the harveſt feaſt: then ſport againe Boyes. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What ſhall I do? live thus unknown, and baſe ſtill?
Or thruſt my ſelf into the head oth' Battell?
And there, like that I am, a Gentleman,
And one that never fear'd the face of danger,
(So in her angry eyes ſhe carried honour)
Fight nobly, and (to end my cares) dye nobly?
SIlvio go on, and raiſe thy noble minde
To noble ends; fling courſe baſe thoughts behinde:
Silvio, thou Sonne of everliving fame,
Now aime at vertue, and a Noble Name.
Silvio conſider, Honour is not wonne,
Nor vertue reach't, till ſome brave thing be done:
Thy Country calls thee now; ſhe burnes, and bleeds,
Now raiſe thy ſelf, young man, to noble deeds.
Into the Battell Silvio, there ſeeke forth
Danger, and blood, by them ſtands ſacred worth.
What heavenly voice is this that followes me?
This is the ſecond time 't has waited on me,
Since I was arm'd, and ready for the Battell;
It names me often, ſteeles my heart with courage,
And in a thouſand ſweet noates comforts me;
What Beldom's this? how old ſhe is, and ugly,
Why do's ſhe follow me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be not diſmaid, Son,
I wait upon thee, for thy good, and honour,
'Twas I that now ſung to thee, ſtir'd thy minde up,
And raiſ'd thy ſpirits to the pitch of nobleneſſe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Though ſhe be old, and of a crooked carkaſſe,
Her voice is like the harmony of Angels.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou art my darling, all my love dwells on thee
The Son of vertue, therefore I attend thee;
Enquire not what I am, I come to ſerve thee,
For if thou beeſt inquiſitive, thou haſt loſt me:
A thouſand long miles hence my dwelling is,
Deep in a Cave, where but mine owne, no foot treads,
There by mine Art, I found what danger (Silvio)
And deep diſtreſſe of heart, thou wert growne into,
A thouſand leagues I have cut through empty aire,
Far ſwifter then the ſayling tack that gallops
Upon the wings of angry winds, to ſeeke thee.
Sometimes 'ore a ſwelling tide, on a Dolphins back I ride,
Sometimes paſſe the earth below, and through the unmoved Center go;
Sometimes in a flame of fire, like a Meteor I aſpire,
Sometimes in mine own ſhape, thus, when I helpe the vertuous,
Men of honourable minds, command my Art in all his kinds;
Purſue the noble thought of war, from thy Guard ile not be far,
Get thee worſhip on thy foe, laſting fame is gotten ſo.
Single Syennas Duke alone, heare thy friends, thy Country grone,
And with thy manly arme ſtrike ſure, then thou haſt wrought thine owne free cure.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Some Sybell ſure, ſome ſoule heaven loves, and favours.
And lends her their free powers, to worke their wonders?
How ſhe incites my courage?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I knew thee many daies a go,
Foreſaw thy love to Belvidere, the Ducheſſe Daughter, and her Heire;
Knew ſhe lov'd thee, and know what paſt, when you were found i'th Caſtle faſt
In one anothers armes; foreſaw the taking of ye, and the Law;
And ſo thy innocence I loved, the deepeſt of my skill I proved;
Be rul'd by me, for to this houre I have dwelt about thee with my powre.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I will, and in the courſe of all obſerve thee,
For thou art ſure an Angell good ſent to me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Get thee gone then to the fight, longer ſtay but robs thy right;
When thou grow'ſt weary ile be neere, then think on beauteous Belvidere,
For every precious thought of her, ile lend thine honour a new ſpurre;
When all is done, meet here at night; Go and be happy in the fight. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I certainly believe I ſhall do nobly,
And that Ile bravely reach at too, or die. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Is ſhe ſo loving ſtill?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: She is mad with love,
As mad as ever unworm'd dogge was, Signior,
And do's ſo weep, and curſe, for your prevention,
Your croſſes in your love; it frets me too,
I am falne away to nothing, to a ſpindle,
Growne a meere man of mat, no ſoule within me,
Pox o' my Maſter, Sir, will that content ye?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: This rogue but cozens me, and ſhe neglects me,
Upon my life there are ſome other gamſters,
Neerer the winde then I, and that prevents me,
Is there no other holds acquaintance with her?
Prethee be true, be honeſt, do not mock me,
Thou knoweſt her heart, no former intereſt
She has vow'd a favour to? and cannot handſomly
Go off, but by regaining ſuch a friendſhip?
There are a thouſand handſom men, young, wealthy,
That will not ſtick at any rate, nor danger,
To gaine ſo ſweet a prize; nor can I blame her,
If where ſhe finds a comfort ſhe deale cunningly,
I am a ſtranger yet.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Ye are all ſhe looks for,
And if there be any other, ſhe neglects all,
And all for you: I would you ſaw how grievouſly
And with what hourely lamentations.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I know thou flatter'ſt me; tell me but truth,
Looke here, look well, the beſt meat in the Dukedom,
The rareſt, and the choiceſt of all diets,
This will I give thee, but to ſatisfie me;
That is, not to diſſemble; this rare Lobſter,
This Pheaſant of the ſea, this diſh for Princes,
And all this thou ſhalt enjoy, eat all thy ſelfe,
Have good Greeke wine, or any thing belongs to it,
A wench if it deſire one.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: All this, Signior?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: All, and a greater far then this.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A greater?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If thou deſerve by telling truth.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A wench too?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Or any thing, but if you play the knave now,
The Cozening knave beſides the loſſe of this,
In which thou haſt parted with a paradiſe,
I neare will give thee meat more, not a morſell,
No ſmell of meat by my meanes ſhall come neere thee,
Nor name of any thing that's nouriſhing,
But to thy old part Tantalus againe,
Thou ſhalt returne, and there ſnap at a ſhadow.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Upon this point, had I intended Treaſon,
Or any thing might call my life in queſtion,
Follow'd with all the tortures time could think on,
Give me but time to eat this lovely Lobſter,
This Alderman o'th Sea, and give me wine to him,
I would reveale all, and if that all were too little,
More then I knew; Bartello holds in with her,
The Captain of the Cittadell, but you need not fear him,
His tongue's the ſtiffeſt weapon that he carries.
He is old, and out of uſe; there are ſome other,
Men young enough, handſome, and bold enough,
Could they come to make their game once; but they want Sir,
They want the unde quare, they are laid by then,
You onely are the man ſhall knock the nayle in—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How now Penurio?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Your Worſhip's fairely met, Sir.
You ſhall heare further from me, ſteale aſide Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Remember your Maſter for thoſe Chaines.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: They are ready, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: What young thing's this? by his habit hee's a Merchant;
I feare he trades my way too, you dryed dog-fiſh,
What bait was that?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Who Sir, the thing went hence now?
A notable young whelp.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: To what end Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Came to buy Chaines and Rings, is to be married,
An Aſſe, a Coxcomb, has nothing in his houſe, Sir;
I warrant you think he came to ſee my Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: I doubt it ſhrewdly.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Away, away, 'tis fooliſh;
He has not the face to look upon a Gentlewoman,
A poore skym'd thing, his Mothers maids are faine, Sir,
To teach him how to kiſſe, and againſt he is married,
To ſhew him on which ſide the ſtirrop ſtands.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: That's a fine youth.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Thou wouldſt hang thy ſelf, that thou hadſt half his power,
Thou empty Potgun.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Am I come fit Penurio?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: As fit as a fiddle,
My Matter's now abroad about his buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: When thou cam'ſt to me home to day, I half ſuſpected
My wife was jealous, that ſhe whiſpered to thee.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: You deſerve well the whil'ſt, ther's no ſuch matter,
She talk'd about ſome toyes my Maſter muſt bring to her,
You muſt not know of.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Ile take noat, Penurio.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No, Nor you ſhall not, till you have it ſoundly.
This is the braveſt Capitano Pompo,
But I ſhall pump ye anon Sir.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: O my Bartello?

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Ye pretty Rogue, you little Rogue, you ſweet Rogue,
Away Penurio, go and walk i'th Horſe-Fayre.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: You do not love me?

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt thou little Raſcall;
There Sirrah, to your Centry.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: How the Colt itches?
Ile help ye to a Curry-comb ſhall claw ye. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: And how much doſt thou love me?

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Let's go in quickly,
Ile tell thee preſently, ile meaſure it to thee.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: No buſſes firſt? ſit 'o my knee, my brave boy,
My valiant boy; do not look ſo fiercely on me,
Thou wilt fright me with thy face; come buſſe againe Chick,
Smile in my face you mad thing.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: I am mad indeed wench,
Precious I am all o' fire.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Ile warrant thee better.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Ile warme thee too, or ile blow out my bellowes;
Ha, ye ſweet rogue, you loving rogue, a Boy now,
A Souldier I will get ſhall prove a fellow.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Miſtris, looke to your ſelfe, my Maſter's comming.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The Devill come, and go with him.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The Devill's come indeed, he brings your wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: We are undone, undone then.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My wife with him?
Why this is a diſmall day.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: They are hard by too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I muſt not, dare not ſee her.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Nor my Husband,
For twenty thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That I were a Cat now,
Or any thing could run into a Bench-hole,
Saint Anthonies Fire upon the Rogue has brought her;
Where ſhall I be? juſt in the nick oth' matter?
When I had her at my mercy: think for heaven ſake,
My wife, all the wilde furies hell has.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Up the Chimney.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: They'l ſmoke me out there preſently.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: There, there, it muſt be there,
We are all undone elſe: it muſt be up the Chimney.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Give me a Ladder.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: You muſt uſe your Art Sir,
Alas, we have no Ladders.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Pox o' thy husband,
Do's he never mend his houſe?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No, nor himſelfe neither:
Up nimbly Sir, up nimbly.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Thou know'ſt I am fat,
Thou mercileſſe leane Rogue.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Will ye be kill'd?
For if he take ye—

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Lend me thy ſhoulder.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Soft Sir,
You'l tread my ſhoulder-bones into my ſides elſe,
Have ye faſt hold oth' barrs?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: A vengeance bar 'em.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Patience good Captain, patience: quickly, quickly.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do you think I am made of ſmoke?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Now he talkes of ſmoke,
What if my Maſter ſhould call for fire?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Will ye Martyr me?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: He muſt needs have it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Will ye make me Bacon?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: We'l do the beſt we can, are all things ready?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: All, all, I have 'em all.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Go, let 'em in then,
Not a word now on your life.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I hang like a Meteor.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: You are welcome Lady.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: You are too too curteous,
But I ſhall make amends, faire Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Welcome my worthy friend, moſt kindely welcome.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: I heare on't, and ile fit him for his foolery.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Some ſweet meats wife: ſome ſweet meats preſently.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: O my ſowre ſauce.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Away quick Iſabella. Exit Iſab.
Did you heare him?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Yes, yes, perfectly, proceed Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Speake loud enough: Dare ye at length but pitty me?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: 'Faith Sir, you have us'd ſo many reaſons to me,
And thoſe ſo powerfully—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Keep this kiſſe for me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And do I ſtand and heare this?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: This for me Sir,
This is ſome comfort now: Alas my Husband—
But why Do I think of ſo poore a fellow,
So wretched, ſo deboſh'd?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That's I, I am bound to heare it.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: I dare not lye with him, he is ſo ranke a Whore-maſter.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And that's a dangerous point.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Upon my conſcience Sir,
He would ſtick a thouſand baſe diſeaſes on me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And now muſt I ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I am ſound Lady.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: That's it that makes me love ye.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Let's kiſſe againe then.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Do, do.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Do, the Devill.
And the grand Pox do with ye.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Do ye heare him? well—
Now, what's the newes with you?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The ſound of War Sir,
Comes ſtill along: The Duke will charge the City,
We have loſt they ſay.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: What ſhall become of me then,
And my poore wealth?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Even hang'd, I hope.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Remove your Jewells preſently,
And what you have of wealth into the Cittadell,
I here all's ſecure.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I humbly thank ye Lady:
Penurio, get me ſome can climbe the Chimney,
For there my Jewells are, my beſt, my richeſt,
I hid 'em, fearing ſuch a blow.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Moſt happily:
I have two Boyes, that uſe to ſweep fould Chimnies,
Truly I brought 'em Sir, to mock your worſhip,
For the great Fires ye keep, and the full diet.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I forgive thee knave, where are they?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Here Sir, here:
Mounſieur Black will your ſmall worſhip mount?

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.l: Madam è be com to creep up into your Chimney, and make you. Boy ſings.
Cleane, as any Lady in de world: Ma litla, litla frera, and è,
Chanta, frere, chanta.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Come Mounſieur, mounte, mountè, mount Mounſieur Muſterd-pot. Boy ſings.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.l: Mounſieur è have dis for votra barba, ple ta von Mounſieur.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Mòunte Mounſieur, mountè dere be ſome fine tings.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.l: Me will creep like de Ferret Mounſieur.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Dere in the Chimney. The Boy above ſinging.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.l: He be de ſheilde due ſhauſon, Madam.

div.stage: Boy goes in behinde the Arras.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: There's a Birds-neaſt, I wound have ye climbe it Mounſieur,
Up my fine ſinging Mounſieur: that's a fine Mounſieur.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Watch him, he do not ſteale.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I warrant ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Theſe Boyes are knaviſh. Boy within, Madam here be de Rat, de Rat Madam.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Ile looke to him tithly

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Lord, what comes here, Boy ſings upon Bartellas ſhoulder.
A walking apparition?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Saint Chriſtopher.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Mercy o' me, what is it?
How like my Husband it lookes?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Get ye downe Devill,
Ile breake your neck elſe: was ever man thus chimnied?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Go pay the Boyes well: ſee them ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Come Mounſieur Devills, come my Black-berries
Ile butter ye o' both ſides.

div.stage: Boye Exit ſaying, Adieu Madam, adieu Madam.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Nay, ev'n look Sir, are you cooled now, Captaine?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I am Cuckolled, and fool'd to boot too:
Fool'd fearefully, fool'd ſhamefully.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: You are welcome Sir,
I am glad I have any thing within theſe doores Sir
To make ye merry; you love my wife, I thank ye,
You have ſhew'd your love.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Wife, am I this? this odde matter,
This monſtrous thing?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: You ought, but yet you are not:
I have been bold with you Sir, but yet not baſely,
As I have faith I have not.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Sir, beleeve it;
'Twas all meant but to make you feele your treſpaſſe;
We new your howre, and all this faſhion'd for it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Were you oth' plot too?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Yes by my troth, ſweet Captaine.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You will forgive me wife?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: You will deſerve it?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Put that toth' venture.

sp.speaker: Rho:
sp.l: Thus am I friends againe then,
And as you ne're had gone aſtray, thus kiſſe ye.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And ile kiſſe you, and you too ask forgiveneſſe;
Kiſſe my wife Lopez, 'tis but in jeſt remember;
And now all friends together to my Caſtle,
Where we'l all dine, and there diſcourſe theſe ſtories,
And let him be Chimney-ſwept in's luſt that glories. Exe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Haile reverent Dame, heaven wait upon thy ſtudies.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You are well met Son: what is the Battell ended?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Mother, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How has thy honour proſper'd?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The Dutcheſſe has the day, Syenna's Priſoner:
Arm'd with thy powrefull Art, this arme diſmounted him,
Receiv'd him then on foot, and in faire valour
Forc'd him mine owne, this Jewell I tooke from him,
It hung upon his cask, the Victors triumph:
And to the Dutcheſſe now a Priſoner
I have renderd him: Come off againe unknown, Mother.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis well done, let me ſee he jewell Son;
'Tis a rich one, curious ſet, fit a Princeſſe Burgonet:
This rich token late was ſent, by the Dutcheſſe with intent
The Marriage next day to begin: Do'ſt thou know what's hid within?
Wipe thine eyes, and then come neere, ſee the beautious Belvidere:
Now behold it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O my Saint.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: We are it nobly, do not faint.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: How bleſt am I in this rich ſpoile, this picture,
For ever will I keep it here, here Mother,
For ever honour it: how oft, how chaſtly
Have I embrac'd the life of this, and kiſt it?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The day drawes on that thou muſt home returne,
And make thy anſwer to the Dutcheſſe queſt on
I know it troubles thee, for if thou faile in't—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O, I muſt dye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Feare not, feare not, ile be nigh,
Caſt thy trouble on my back, art nor cunning ſhal not lack
To preſerve thee, ſtill to keepe, what thy envious foemen ſeeke;
Go boldly home, and let thy minde, no diſtruſtfull croſſes finde:
All ſhall happen for the beſt; ſouls walk through ſorrowes that are bleſt.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Then I go confident.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But firſt my Son, a thankfull ſervice muſt be done,
The good old woman for her paine, when every thing ſtands faire againe,
Muſt ask a poore Boon, and that granting, there's nothing to thy journey wanting.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Except the triall of my ſoul to miſchief,
And as I am a Knight, and love mine honour,
I grant it whatſoever.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thy pure ſoule
Shall never ſinke for me, nor howle.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Then any thing.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: When I ſhall aske remember.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: If I forget, heavens goodneſſe forget me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: On thy journey then a while, to the next croſſe way and ſtile
Ile conduct thee, keepe thee true, to thy Miſtris and thy vow,
And let all their envies fall, ile be with thee and quench all.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: LAdy, the ſtubborn war's more milde then you are,
That allowes Ranſome, and the Priſoner taken—

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: We muſt not be too haſty: Remember Sir,
The wrong and violence you have offer'd us,
Burnt up our Frontire Townes, made prey before ye
Both of our Beaſts, and Corne; ſlaine our deare Subjects,
Open'd the fountaine eyes of thouſand widowes,
That daily fling their curſes on your fury;
What ordinary ſatisfaction can ſalve this?
What haſty thought-on Ranſome give a remedy?
You muſt excuſe us yet, we'l take more counſell:
In the meane time, not as a Priſoner,
But as a noble Prince we entertaine ye.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I am at your mercy Lady, 'tis my fortune,
My ſtubborne fate; the day is yours, you have me,
The valour of one ſingle man has croſs'd me,
Croſt me and all my hope; for when the Battells
Were at the hotteſt game of all their furies,
And conqueſt ready then to crowne me Victor,
One ſingle man broke in, one ſword, one vertue,
And by his great example thouſands followed,
O how I ſhame to think on't, how it ſhakes me!
Nor could our ſtrongeſt head then ſtop his fury,
But like a tempeſt 'bore the field before him,
Till he arriv'd at me, with me he buckell'd,
A while I held him play; at length his violence
Beat me from my Saddle, then on foot purſu'd me,
There triumph'd once againe, then tooke me Priſoner:
When I was gone a feare poſſeſt my people.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: One ſingle arme, in a juſt dauſe, heaven proſpers.
Is not this ſtranger Knight as yet diſcover'd,
That we may give his vertue a doe honour?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Not yet that we hear Madam, but to that purpoſe,
Two dayes ago we publiſh'd Proclamations

div.stage: Enter Soto with a Trumpet, and Silvio.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: O dainty Ducheſſe, here I bring that Knight
Before thy fragrant face, that warlike wight,
He that Syenna's Duke, and all his Louts
Beat (as the Proverb ſeemly ſayes) to clouts:
He that unhorſs'd the man of fame to boot,
And bootleſſe taught his Grace to walk afoot:
He that your writings (pack'd to every pillar)
Promis'd promotion to, and ſtore of filler,
That very man I ſet before thy Grace,
And once againe pronounce this man it was.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: A pretty fooliſh Squire, what muſt the Knight be?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Some Jugler, or ſome Mad-man.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I was not ſo,
When thy faint Troopes in flockes I beat before me,
When through the thickeſt of thy warlike horſe
I ſhot my ſelfe, even to thy Standard Duke,
And there found thee, there fingled thee, there ſhew'd thee
The temper of my Sword. 'Tis true, thou ſtood'ſt me,
And like a noble Souldier bid'ſt me welcome;
And this ile ſay, More honour in that arme
I found and tryed, then all thy Army carried:
What followes thy Imprisonment can tell thee.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: His faire relation carries truth and vertue,
And by thoſe Armes I ſee (for ſuch were his,
So old, ſo ruſty) this may be he that forc'd me.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Do you know this Jewell, from your Cask I rent it,
Even as I clos'd, and forced ye from your ſaddle;
Do you now remember me?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: This is the valour
Madam, for certaine he, it muſt be he,
That day I wore this Jewell, you remember it.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Yes, very well; not long before I ſent it.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: That day I loſt this Jewell, in fight I loſt it,
I felt his ſtroakes, and felt him take it from me,
I wore it in my Cask; take it againe Sir,
You won it nobly, 'tis the prize of honour.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: My Father, and my ſelfe are made for ever.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.l: Kneele down brave Sir, thus my Knight firſt I raiſe ye,
Gird on a Sword; next Generall of my Army,
Give him a Staffe; laſt, one in Counſell neare me.
Now, make us happy with your ſight: how? Silvio?
Have I on thee beſtow'd this love, this honour?
The Treaſons thou haſt wrought ſet off with favours?
Unarme him preſently: O thou foule Traitor,
Traitor to me, mine honour, and my Country,
Thou kindler of theſe Warres.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Miſtake not Madam.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Away with him to priſon,
See him ſafe kept, the Law ſhall ſhortly Sirra,
Finde fitter titles for ye, then I gave ye.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: This is the youth that kild me, ile be quit with him,
What a blinde rogue was I, I could never know him?
And't pleaſe your Grace, I claime the benefit
Of the Proclamation that proclam'd him Traitor,
I brought him in.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt have thy reward for't.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Let him be hang'd, or drown'd then.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Madam, I crave your promiſe firſt; you are tyed to it,
You have paſt your Princely word.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Prove it, and take it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: This is the day appointed,
Appointed by your Grace for my appearance,
To anſwer to the Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I remember it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I claime it then,

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: If you performe it not,
The penalty you claime too.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I not repent it;
If I abſolve the words?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Your life is free then,
You have drawne a ſpeedy courſe above my wiſhes,
To my rezenge, be ſure ye hit it right,
Or ile be ſure you ſhall not ſcape the danger.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: My reſt is up now Madam.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Then play it cunningly.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Now, where's the Hag? where now are all her promiſes,
She would be with me, ſtrengthen me, informe me?
My death will now be double death, ridiculous:
She was wont ſtill to be neare, to feele my miſeries,
And with her Art, I ſee her no where now;
What have I undertaken? now ſhe failes me,
No comfort now I finde, how my ſoule ſtaggers?
Till this houre never fear, nor doubt poſſeſt me,
She cannot come, ſhe will not come, ſhe has fool'd me;
Sure, ſhe is the Devill, has drawne me on to ruine,
And now to death bequeaths me in my danger.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He ſtands diſtracted, and his colour changes.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I have given him that will make his blood forſake him;
Shortly his life.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: His hands and contemplation
Have motion ſtill, the reſt is earth already.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.l: Come, will ye ſpeak or pray? your time growes out Sir;
How every where he looks? he's at laſt caſt.

div.stage: Enter Belvidere, and ſecretly gives him a paper, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: His colour comes againe freſh.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.l: 'Tis a flaſh, Sir,
Before the flame burnes out; can ye yet anſwer?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Yes Madam, now I can.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: I feare you'l faile in't.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And do not think my ſilence a preſage,
Or Omen to my end, you ſhall not finde it;
I am bred a Souldier, not an Orator,
Madam, peruſe this ſcrowle, let that ſpeake for me,
And as you are Royall, wrong not the conſtruction.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: By Heaven you ſhall have faire play.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I ſhall looke for't.
Tell me what it that onely thing,
For which all women long;
Yet having what they moſt deſire,
To have it do's them wrong.
Tis not to be chaſte, nor faire,
Such gifts malice may impaire;
Richly trim'd, to walke or ride,
Or to wanton uneſpi'd;
To preſerve an honeſt name,
And ſo to give it up to fame;
Theſe are toyes. In good or ill
They deſire, to have their will;
Yet when they have it, they abuſe it,
For they know not how to uſe it.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: You have anſwer'd right, and gain'd your life,
I give it.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O happy Hag! But my moſt gracious Madam,
Your promiſe tide a nobler favour to me.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: 'Tis true, my daughter too.

sp.speaker: Sil
sp.l: I hope you will keep it.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.l: 'Tis not in my powre now, ſhe is long ſince wanderd,
Stolne from the Court, and me; and what I have not
I cannot give: no man can tell me of her,
Nor no ſearch finde her out: and if not Silvio,
Which ſtrongly I beleeve—

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Mock me not Lady,
For as I am a ſervant to her vertue,
Since my firſt howre of exile, I ne're ſaw her

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: That ſhe is gone 'tis too too true, and lamentable,
Our laſt hope was in you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What do I heare then,
And wherefore have I life beſtow'd and honour?
To what end do I walk? for men to wonder at,
And fight, and foole? pray ye take your honours from me,
(My ſorrowes are not fit companions for 'em)
And when ye pleaſe my life: Art thou gone Miſtris,
And wander'ſt heaven knowes where? this vow I make thee,
That till I finde thee out, and ſee thoſe faire eyes,
Thoſe eyes that ſhed their lights, and life into me,
Never to know a friend, to ſeeke a kindred,
To reſt where pleaſure dwells, and painted glory,
But through the world, the wide world thus to wander,
The wretched world alone, no comfort with me,
But the meere meditations of thy goodneſſe:
Honour and greatneſſe, thus adieu.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stay Silvio,
And Lady ſit againe, I come for Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: What would ſhe now?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: To claime thy promiſe Silvio,
The Boone thou ſwor'ſt to give me.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: What may this be,
A woman, or a Devill?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: 'Tis a Witch ſure,
And by her meanes he came to untwiſt this Riddle,

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: That I am bound to her for my liffe, mine honour,
And many other thouſand waies for comfort
I here confeſſe: Confeſſe a promiſe too,
That what ſhe would aske me to requite theſe favours,
Within the endeavour of my life to grant,
I would; and here I ſtand my words full maſter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I wiſh no more: great Lady, witneſſe with me,
The Boone I crave for all my ſervice to thee,
Is now to be thy wife, to grant me marriage.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: How? for to marry thee? aske againe woman,
Thou wilfull woman, aske againe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No more Sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Aske land, and life.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I aske thee for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Soto.
sp.l: Marry her, and beat her into Gun-powder,
She would make rare Crackers.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Aske a better fortune,
Thou art too old to marry: I a Souldier,
And alwaies married to my ſword.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thy word Foole,
Breake that, and ile breake all thy fortunes yet.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: He ſhall not,
I am witneſſe to his faith: and ile compell it.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: 'Tis fit ye hold your word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O moſt wretched.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: This was a fortune now beyond my wiſhes,
For now my Daughter's free, if e're I finde her.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: But not from me.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: You are ſharer in this happineſſe,
My ſelfe will wait upon this marriage,
And do the old woman all the honour poſſible.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ile lead the Knight, and what there wants in dalliance,
Wee'l take it out in drinke.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: O wretched Silvio. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Haſt thou ſent for him?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Yes,

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: A young man, ſaiſt thou?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Yes, very young, and very amarous.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And handſom?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: As the Town affords.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: And dar'ſt thou
Be ſo farre good, and Miſtris of thine honour,
To ſleight theſe?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: For my husbands ſake to curſe 'em,
And ſince you have made me Miſtris of my fortune,
Never to point at any ioy, but husband,
I could have cozen'd ye, but ſo much I love ye,
And now ſo much I weigh the eſtimation
Of an unſpotted wife—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I dare believe thee,
And never more ſhall doubt torment my ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: How now Penurio?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The thing is comming, Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Ile take my ſtanding.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Do, and ile take mine. Exit Lopes.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Where didſt thou leave him?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I left him in a Cellar,
Where he has paid me titely, paid me home Miſtris,
We had an hundred & fifty healths to you, ſweet Miſtris,
And three ſcore and ten damnations to my Maſter;
Miſtris, ſhall I ſpeak a fooliſh word to ye?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: What's that Penurio?
The fellow's drunke.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I would faine know your body.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: How's that? how's that prethee?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I would know it carnally,
I would conglutinate.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: The reaſon ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Lobſter, ſweet Miſtris, Lobſter.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Thy Maſter heares.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Lobſter, ſweet Maſter, Lobſter.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Thou art the moſt precious rogue.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Moſt pretious Lobſter.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Do you ſee who's here? go ſleep ye drunken raſcall.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Remember you refuſe me arm'd in Lobſter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: O my loſt Rugio, welcome, welcome, welcome,
A thouſand welcomes here Ile ſeale.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Pray ye ſtay, Lady,
Do you love me ever at this rate? or is the fit now,
By reaſon of ſome wrong done by your husband,
More fervent on ye?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Can I chuſe but love thee?
Thou art my Martyr, thou haſt ſuffered for me,
My ſweet, ſweet Rugio.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do you do this ſeriouſly?
'Tis true, I would be entertained thus.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Theſe are nothing,
No kiſſes, no embraces, no endeerements,
To thoſe—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do what you will.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Thoſe that ſhall follow,
Thoſe I will crowne our love withall; why ſigh ye?
Why look ye ſad my deere one?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay faith nothing,
But me thinks ſo ſweet a beauty, as yours ſhowes to me,
And ſuch an innocence as you may make it,
Should hold a longer Siege.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Ha, you ſpeake truth, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I would not have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: And now methinkes,
Now I conſider truly what becomes me,
I have been cozen'd, fearefully abus'd,
My reaſon blinded.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay, I did but jeſt with ye.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Ile take ye at your word, and thank ye for't Sir;
And now I ſee no ſweetneſſe in that perſon,
Nothing to ſtir me to abuſe a Husband,
To ruine my faire fame.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Good Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: No hanſome man, no any thing to doat on,
No face, no tongue to catch me, poore at all points,
And I an aſſe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why do ye wrong me Lady?
If I were thus, and had no youth upon me,
My ſervice of ſo meane a way to win ye,
(Which you your ſelfe are conſcious muſt deſerve ye,
If you had thrice the beauty you poſſeſſe, muſt reacht ye)
If in my tongue your fame lay wrack't, and ruin'd
With every cup I drink: if in opinion
I were a loſt, defam'd man: but this is common
Where we love moſt, where moſt we ſtake our fortunes,
There leaſt and baſeſt we are rewarded: fare ye well,
Know now I hate you too as much, contemne ye,
And weigh my credit at as high a value.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: May be I did but jeſt.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ye are a woman,
And now I ſee your wants, and mine owne follies,
And task my ſelfe with indiſcretion,
For doating on a face ſo poore.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Say ye ſo Sir,
(I muſt not loſe my end) I did but jeſt with you,
Only fool'd thus to try your faith: my Rugio,
Do you think I could forget?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Is't poſſible I ſhould forſake a conſtancy,
So ſtrong, ſo good, ſo ſweet?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: A ſubtle woman.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: You ſhall forgive me, 'twas a trick to try ye,
And were I ſure ye lov'd me—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Do you doubt now?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I do not doubt, but he that would profeſſe this,
And beare that full affection you make ſhew of,
Should do—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What ſhould I do?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I cannot ſhew ye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ile try thee damnedſt Devill: hark ye Lady,
No man ſhall dare do more, no ſervice top me,
Ile marry ye.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Your husbands ſentenc'd,
And he ſhall dye.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Dye?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Dye for ever to ye,
The danger is mine owne.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Dye did ye tell me?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: He ſhall dye, I have caſt the way.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: O foule man,
Malicious bloody man.

sp.speaker: Lop,
sp.l: When ſhall he dye Sir,
By whom, and how?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Haſt thou betray'd me, woman?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Baſe man, thou wouldſt have ruin'd me, my name too,
And like a Toad, poyſon'd my vertuous memory:
Further then all this, doſt thou ſee this friend here,
This only friend, ſhame take thy luſt and thee,
And ſhake thy ſoule, his life, the life I love thus,
My life in him, my only life thou aim'dſt at.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Am I catch's thus?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: The Law ſhall catch ye better.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: You make a trade of betraying womens honours,
And think it noble in ye to be luſtfull,
Report of me hereafter—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Fool'd thus finely?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I muſt intreat ye walk, Sir, to the Juſtice,
Where if hee'l bid ye kill me—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Pray ſtay a while, Sir,
I muſt uſe a Players ſhift, do you know me now Lady?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Your brother Claudio ſure.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: O me, 'tis he Sir,
O my beſt brother.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My beſt ſiſter now too,
I have tryed ye, found ye ſo, and now I love ye,
Love ye ſo truly nobly.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Sir, I thank ye,
You have made me a moſt happy man.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Thank her Sir,
And from this houre preſerve that happineſſe,
Be no more fool'd with jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I have loſt it,
And take me now new borne againe, new natur'd.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I do, and to that promiſe tye this faith,
Never to have a falſe thought tempt my vertue.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Enough, enough, I muſt deſire your preſence,
My Cozen Rhodope has ſent in all haſt for us,
I am ſure you will be welcome.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Ile wait on ye.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: What the Project is—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: We ſhall know when we are there, Sir. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Joy to you Silvio, and your young faire Bride,
You have ſtolne a day upon us; you cannot wooe Sir.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: The joyes of Hell hang over me, O miſchiefe,
To what a fortune has the Devill driven me?
Am I reſerv'd for this?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Beſhrew me Sir,
But you have gotten you a right faire bedfellow,
Let you alone to chuſe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I beſeech your Grace,
'Tis miſery enough to have met the Devill,
Not mens reproches too.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: How old is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: A very Girle, her eye delivers it.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Her teeth are ſcarce come yet.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: What goodly children
Will they two have now? ſhe is rarely made to bread on,
What a ſweet timberd body?

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Knotty i'th back,
But will hold out the ſtronger; What a noſe?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I marry, ſuch a noſe, ſo rarely mounted,
Upon my conſcience, 'twas the part he doted on.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: And that fine little eye to it, like an Elephants.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Yes, if her feet were round, and her ears ſachells.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: For any thing we know.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Have ye no mercy?
No pitty in your bloods, to uſe a wretch thus?
You Princes, in whoſe hearts the beſt compaſſions,
Neereſt to thoſe in Heaven, ſhould finde fit places,
Why do you mock at miſery? Fling ſcornes and baſeneſſe
Upon his broken back, that ſinks with ſorrowes?
Heaven may reward you too, and an houre come,
When all your great deſignes ſhall ſhew ridiculous,
And your hearts pinch'd like mine.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Fye Sir, ſo angry
Upon your wedding day? go ſmug your ſelfe,
The Maid will come anon: what Muſick's this?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I warrant you ſome noble preparation.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Let's take our places then.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: More of theſe Devills dumps?
Muſt I be ever haunted with theſe witchcrafts?

div.stage: Enter a Masquerado of ſeverall Shapes and Daunces, after which enter Belvidere and diſperſes them, before the Maskers enter two Preſenters, among which are Bartello, Lopez, Claudio, Iſabella, Rhodope, Soto, Penurio, Jaquenet.

sp.speaker: 1. Pre.
sp.l: Roome, roome for merry ſpirits, roome,
Hether on command we come,
From the good old Beldam ſent,
Cares and ſorrowes to prevent.
Looke up Silvio, ſmile, and ſing,
After winter comes a ſpring.
Feare not faint foole what may follow,
Eyes that now are ſunk and hollow,
By her Art may quick returne
To their flames againe, and burne.
Art commands all youth, and blood,
Strength and beauty it makes good.
Feare not then, diſpaire not, ſing
Round about as we do ſpring:
Cares and ſorrowes caſt away,
This is the old wives holy-day.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Who is this?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: The ſhape of Belvidere.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now Silvio,
How do'ſt thou like me now?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Thus I kneele to thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stand up, and come no nearer, mark me well too,
For if thou troubleſt me I vaniſh inſtantly:
Now chuſe wiſely or chuſe never,
One thou muſt enjoy for ever.
Do'ſt thou love me thus?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Moſt dearely.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Take heed foole, it concernes thee nearely.
If thou wilt have me young and bright,
Pleaſing to thine eye and ſight,
Courtly, and admir'd of all,
Take heed leaſt thy fame do fall,
I ſhall then be full of ſcorne,
Wanton, proud, beware the horne,
Hating what I lov'd before,
Flattery apt to fall before,
All conſuming, nothing getting,
Thus thy faire name comes to ſetting.
But if old and free from theſe
Thou ſhalt chuſe me, I ſhall pleaſe:
I ſhall then maintaine thee ſtill,
With my vertue and my skill:
Still encreaſe and build thy name,
Chuſe now Silvio, here I am.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I know not what to ſay, which way to turne me,
Into thy Soveraigne will I put my anſwer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I thank ye Sir, and my will thus rewards ye,
Take your old Love, your beſt, your deareſt Silvio:
No more Spells now, nor further ſhapes to alter me,
I am thy Belvidere indeed, Deare Mother,
There is no altering this; heavens hand is with it:
And now you ought to give me, he has fairely won me.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: But why that Hag?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: In that ſhape moſt ſecure ſtill,
I followed all your fortunes, ſerv'd, and counſell'd ye,
I met ye at the Farmers firſt a Country wench,
Where fearing to be knowne I tooke that habit,
And to make ye laughing ſport at this mad marriage,
By ſecret ayde of my friend Rhodope
We got this Maske.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: And I am ſure I have ye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: For ever now, for ever.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: You ſee it muſt be,
The wheele of deſtiny hath turn'd it round ſo.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: It muſt, it is, and curs'd be he that breakes it.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Ile put a choyce to you Sir: ye are my Priſoner.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I am ſo, and I muſt be ſo, till it pleaſe you—

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Chuſe one of theſe, either to pay a Ranſome,
At what rate I ſhall ſet it, which ſhall be high enough,
And ſo returne a Free-man, and a Bachellor,
Or give me leave to give you a fit wife,
In honour every way your Graces equall,
And ſo your Ranſom's paid.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: You ſay moſt nobly,
Silvio's example's mine, pray chuſe you for me.

sp.speaker: Duc.
sp.l: I thank ye Sir, I have got the maſtry too,
And here I give your Grace a husbands freedome,
Give me your hand, my Husband.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: You much honour me,
And I ſhall ever ſerve ye for this favour.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Come Lopez, let us give our wives the breeches too,
For they will have 'em.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Whilſt they rule with vertue
Ile give 'em, skin and all.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Wee'l ſcratch it off elſe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: I am glad ye live, more glad ye live to honour,
And from this houre a ſtronger love dwell with us;
Pray you take your man againe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: He knowes my houſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: 'Tis ſin to keep you longer from your Loves,
Wee'l lead the way; and you young men that know not
How to preſerve a wife, and keep her faire,
Give 'em their ſoveraign wills, & pleas'd they are. Exeunt.
